questions.Summary: Application of a mask at a target CPAP of 10 cmH2O improves ventilation and decreases the frequency and severity of hypoxemia in OSA.

choices.Reason: A is correct. This is a case of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which presents as snoring, daytime sleepiness and headaches, and elevated blood pressure. OSA is common among obese patients. The ideal ventilator management for OSA is  CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure).

questions.Statement: What is the type of mechanical ventilation in which the provider determines how many mandatory, fixed-volume breaths the ventilator must deliver while allowing the patient to spontaneously breathe in between?
questions.Summary: SIMV is a type of ventilation that the operator sets fixed-volume breaths while allowing the patient to spontaneously breathe in between.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. A volume-cycled mode of ventilation is AC ventilation. The ventilator will give a fixed tidal volume (VT) at predetermined intervals of time or whenever the patient begins to breathe. No matter the compliance, peak, or plateau pressures in the lungs, the VT provided by the ventilator in AC will always be the same.

B is incorrect. In the positive pressure mechanical ventilation mode known as pressure support ventilation (PSV), the patient initiates each breath. PSV can be administered using invasive mechanical ventilation (through an endotracheal tube) or non-invasive mechanical ventilation (through a full-face or nasal mask).

C is correct. In synchronized intermitent mandatory ventilation, the operator sets the number of mandatory breaths of fixed volume to be delivered by the ventilator.  In this mode mandatory breaths are deivered in synchrony with the patient's inspiratory efforts at a frequency determined by the operator.

D is incorrect. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is a type of positive airway pressure that is used to maintain a predetermined pressure in the airways during both inspiration and expiration of the breathing cycle.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Prolonged mechanical ventilation as a complication of ARDS will require tracheostomy in the recovery period. The tracheostomy makes it easier to remove the secretions and easier to wean off the ventilator.

questions.Summary: Ventilation in the prone position leads to an immediate and long-term improvement in oxygenation as a result of more uniform lung inflation, enhanced alveolar recruitment, increased functional residual capacity, redistribution of regional lung perfusion, changes in diaphragmatic motility, and better secretion clearance.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Prone ventilation causes enhanced alveolar recruitment and improved oxygenation.

questions.Summary: Airway pressure release ventilation (APRV), is also referred to as Bi-level Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP) or pressure-control ventilation with pressure support (PCV+), depending on the manufacturer. It is a form of pressure-controlled, time-cycled mode of ventilation that provides two different levels of CPAP (P-high and P-low) with an inverse I:E ratio and allows spontaneous breathing at both levels of CPAP.  An APRV P-high should be between 15-30 cm H20 and P-low between 0-5 cm H2O.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is a case of acute lung injury which is managed with airway pressure release ventilation (APRV). An APRV P-high setting of 30 cm H2O is within the acceptable range of 15-30 cmH2O.

B is incorrect. This is a case of acute lung injury which is managed with airway pressure release ventilation (APRV). An APRV P-high setting of 20 cm H2O is within the acceptable range of 15-30 cmH2O.
C is incorrect. This is a case of acute lung injury which is managed with airway pressure release ventilation (APRV). An APRV P-low setting of 5 cm H2O is within the acceptable range of 0-5 cmH2O.
D is correct. This is a case of acute lung injury which is managed with airway pressure release ventilation (APRV). An APRV P-low setting of 10 cm H2O is not within the acceptable range of 0-5 cmH2O.

questions.Summary: Management strategies of tension pneumothorax depend on the hemodynamic stability of the patient. If unstable, immediate needle decompression is performed without delay. However, the risk of lung re-expansion remains so a chest tube would be the next step. Serial chest X-rays are typically performed to monitor afterwards.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. A chest x-ray would be futile in a situation that requires immediate action. It would delay the management and increase the risk of mortality.
B is incorrect. A chest tube thoracostomy would be the definitive management of pneumothorax after needle thoracostomy is done.

C is correct. This is an emergency situation involving a tension pneumothorax. Needle thoracostomy at the second intercostal space along the mid-clavicular line would be the immediate course of treatment. Definitive management includes insetion of a chest tube after the tension is released.

questions.Summary: The apex is the region most vulnerable to barotrauma. Because the apical alveoli are already partially distended, an increase in air pressure may cause barotrauma in these areas first, before spreading to the rest of the lung.

questions.Statement: A 48-year-old obese man was admitted to the hospital with ST-elevation myocardial infarction. On the sixth day of his hospitalization, he had a sudden decrease in sensorium, hypotension, and irregular pulses. You suspected a reinfarction. Which of the following cardiac enzymes would be most likely to confirm your diagnosis?
questions.Summary: Within 2 to 3 hours of the onset of chest discomfort, circulating troponin levels normally begin to rise. At that point, the levels will keep rising until a peak is reached, which typically takes between 12 and 48 hours. Over the following 4 to 10 days, the troponin level will start to decrease until it reaches a normal level. CK-MB returns to normal in 2-3 days.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Following a myocardial infarction, CK-MB returns to normal in 2-3 days. Elevation that appears suddenly may indicate reinfarction.

B is incorrect. Within 2 to 3 hours of the onset of chest discomfort, circulating troponin levels normally begin to rise. At that point, the levels will keep rising until a peak is reached, which typically takes between 12 and 48 hours. Over the following 4 to 10 days, the troponin level will start to decrease until it reaches a normal level. Since it only took 5 days for another event to happen, the use of Troponin I would be futile in this case.

C is incorrect. Following a myocardial infarction, LDH isoenzyme levels typically rise for 24 to 72 hours before reaching a peak concentration in 3 to 4 days. It serves as a late signal for myocardial infarction because the levels are increased for 8 to 14 days.

D is incorrect. After an acute MI, the blood level of AST rises 3 to 4 hours hours later, peaks between 15 and 28 hours later, and recovers to baseline within 5 days. Because AST is not a specific marker for cardiac myocytes, it has lost favor in clinical practice for the diagnosis of acute MI.

questions.Statement: After arguing with her husband, a 27 year-old woman comes to the ER complaining of excruciating chest discomfort. ER workup includes an ECG, revealing ST-segment depression on V1–V6. The chest pain eventually disappears after 30 minutes.  A coronary angiogram reveals no abnormalities. What is the diagnosis?
questions.Summary: Prinzmetal or vasospastic angina is an often underdiagnosed form of angina pectoris. It is associated with transient ECG changes and retained maximal exercise capacity.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Unstable angine may present as a hyperacute T-wave, flattening of the T-waves, inverted T-wave, and ST depression on the ECG.  One characteristic of unstable angina is that the pain may not totally resolve despite appropriate treatment.  Additionally, these patients may be aware of the symptoms and report a rise in chest pain episodes that last longer as well as an aggravation of the symptoms.

B is correct. This is a case of Prinzmetal angina, also referred to as vasospastic angina. During an episode of chest discomfort, these individuals typically experience ischemia ST-segment abnormalities on an ECG, which return to normal when the symptoms pass. The patients are usually younger in age.

C is incorrect. Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) typically manifests as a pressure-like substernal ache usually lasting more than ten minutes. The discomfort may extend to the neck, jaw, or either arm. Patients with symptoms associated with acute coronary syndrome and elevated troponin levels but no ECG alterations consistent with STEMI are diagnosed with NSTEMI.
D is incorrect. STEMI is characterized by ST changes on the ECG and can only be diagnosed when troponin elevation has been confirmed.

questions.Statement: A 68-year-old man complains of chest pain whenever he climbs his apartment stairs or walks uphill. Upon consultation, you note a grade 2 systolic ejection murmur and a carotid upstroke on palpation. The most likely diagnosis would be:
questions.Summary: Aortic stenosis is a common valvular pathology leading to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. It is typically auscultated as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, with the possibility of an opening click being present.

choices.Reason:
A is incorrect.  Mitral stenosis usually presents 20 to 40 years after an incident of rheumatic fever. Due to greater effort used to close the mitral valve, the first cardiac sound on auscultation is often loud and sometimes palpable.
If significant pulmonary hypertension is brought on by mitral stenosis, the P2 (pulmonic) component of the second heart sound (S2) will be loud. The murmur heard in mitral stenosis is a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur with presystolic accentuation. It makes a low-pitched murmur.

B is incorrect. The cause of mitral regurgitation (MR) is the retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle (LV) into the left atrium (LA) through the mitral valve (MV).  MR causes a systolic murmur that may be heard most clearly at the top of the heart and extending to the left axilla,

C is correct. This is a case of Aortic stenosis which presents as exertional dyspnea and angina both noted in the patient. It typically affects individuals 50 to 70 years old. Carotid upstroke can be observed on palpation. A slow-rising, late-peaking, and a low-amplitude carotid impulse, pulsus parvus et tardus, is an expected finding in severe aortic stenosis and, when present, is specific to aortic stenosis. On auscultation, the second heart sound may not have a split and is heard as a continuous sound during inspiration. A mid-systolic ejection murmur with radiation into the right neck is most audible over the right second intercostal region.

D is incorrect. Due to systolic hypertension and decreased diastolic pressure, Aortic regurgitation is linked to a widened pulse pressure. The inferiorly and laterally displaced apical LV impulse is hyperdynamic. At the base of the heart, the suprasternal notch, and above the carotid arteries, a significant systolic thrill may be felt.

questions.Statement: A pansystolic murmur was heard at the left parasternal border during auscultation of a patient known to have a valvular heart abnormality. The murmur gets louder during inspiration. The damaged valve is:
questions.Summary: Inspiration will increase the venous return to the right side of the heart due to a negative intra-thoracic pressure. This leads to increased preload to the right side of the heart and increased flow across right heart valves.

questions.Statement: A recently diagnosed diabetic patient visited the emergency room after experiencing frequent lightheadedness, cold sweats, and palpitations for a week after starting treatment. Which drug was most likely administered to the patient?
questions.Summary: Sulfonoylureas are insulin secretagouges and can result in hypoglycemia.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The patient is experiencing hypoglycemia precipitated by the prescribed medication. Of the options presented, only sulfonoylureas are insulin secretagouges and can result in hypoglycemia.
B is incorrect. Biguanides are not significantly correlated with a risk of hypoglycemia because they do not raise insulin levels.
C is incorrect. When administered alone or in combination with other medications that do not cause hypoglycemia, alpha-glucosidase inhibitors do not result in hypoglycemia.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old male with a history of DM presents for an inguinal mass that appeared after he lifted a heavy box. Upon examination, a bulge appears when standing up and vanishes when lying down. You admit him and schedule him for inguinal repair. How do you prepare him before surgery?
questions.Summary: Poor preoperative glycemic control is associated with an increased complication rate and reduced survival after surgery. A carbohydrate load 2 hours prior to surgery is one of the recommended interventions in the ERAS protocols.

choices.OptionStatement: Put him on NPO 8 hours prior to prevent aspiration
choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  Prolonged fasting should be avoided in DM as it is associated with worse perioperative glycemic control.
B is incorrect.The majority of oral diabetes medications are safe to take up until the day before surgery, and some drugs are safe to take on the day of surgery.

C is correct. In patients having major abdominal surgery, carbohydrate loading two hours before to surgery as part of the Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol combats insulin resistance brought on by stress and deprivation, lowers postoperative hyperglycemia, and shortens hospital stay.
D is incorrect. For patients on insulin, a dose reduction is often advised the day before and the day of surgery to prevent hypoglycemia brought on by fasting.

questions.Summary: The artery compressed in subfalcine herniation is the anterior cerebral artery which causes infarction and leg paralysis on the contralateral side.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is a case of subfalcine herniation with anterior cerebral artery compression.
B is correct. The artery compressed in subfalcine herniation is the anterior cerebral artery which causes infarction and leg paralysis on the contralateral side.
C is incorrect. This is a case of subfalcine herniation with anterior cerebral artery compression.
D is incorrect. Compression of the basilar artery leads to tearing and bleeding. This can also cause compression of the pituitary stalk which leads to diabetes insipidus.

questions.Statement: A 28 year old biker was rushed to the ER due to dyspnea, headache and blindness in one eye. On physical examination, his GCS score was 10 and his right pupil was dilated and fixed. A CT scan was performed which showed a mass on the temporal lobe. What is the mechanism behind this diagnosis?
questions.Summary: Skull trauma can lead to a variety of symptoms depending on the resultant pathology. A proper history and physical exam can lead to a preliminary diagnosis in the absence of diagnostic imaging.

choices.OptionStatement: Pressure on the temporal lobe leading to compression of the midbrain and the 3rd cranial nerve and posterior cerebral artery.
choices.Reason: A is correct. This is a case of transtentorial uncal herniation which involves pressure on the temporal lobe and compression of the midbrain. The uncus herniation causes compression of the 3rd cranial nerve (unilateral dilated and fixed pupil, eye deviation) and posterior cerebral artery (causing contralateral homonymous hemianopia).

choices.OptionStatement: Pressure on the brainstem which leads to compression of the third ventricle and the superior cerebellar arteries.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. This description is characteristic of transtentorial upward herniation in which an infratentorial mass pushes the brain stem upward through the tentorium. This causes compression of the third ventricle and superior cerebellar arteries.

choices.OptionStatement: Pressure on the cerebellar tonsils and herniation through the foramen magnum.
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. This is a description characteristic of cerebellar tonsils herniation. An infratentorial mass causes increased pressure on the cerebellar tonsils and leads to herniation through the foramen magnum.

choices.OptionStatement: Trauma to the skull leading to brain herniation through the path of least resistance.
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. This is a description of transcalvarial herniation that results from a trauma or fracture in the skull. The brain herniates through the path of least resistance causing stretching of brain structures.

questions.Statement: A 27 year old woman was brought to the ER unconscious. Her partner reported she had been experiencing headaches for days and saw her vomit a few times today. A CT scan was done which showed an infratentorial hemorrhage compressing the cerebellar tonsils. What is your diagnosis?

questions.Statement: A 23 year old college student comes to your clinic with a chief complaint of weight loss. He endorses poor concentration and decreased energy to complete his thesis. He says this is because of stress and lack of sleep. What is initial drug of choice?
questions.Summary: SSRIs are the most widely prescribed antidepressants for the treatment of mild to moderate depression, obsessive-compulsive syndrome, panic disorder, social phobias, and posttraumatic stress disorder. questions.Statement: A 30 year old actress has been suffering from abnormal sweating in her underarms. She consulted a surgeon and underwent sympathectomy to mange her symptoms.  After her procedure, she has been experiencing orthostatic hypotension. This symptom can best be explained by:
questions.Summary: Arterial baroreceptors control the sympathetic drive to the heart and the peripheral blood vessels. They constantly adjust the sympathetic activity in relation to systemic blood pressure changes in order to maintain homeostasis.

choices.OptionStatement: An exaggerated response of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. An exaggerated response of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) leads to vasoconstriction leading to increased blood pressure.

choices.OptionStatement: A suppressed response of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. A suppressed response of the RAAS would lead to decreased blood pressure and organ perfusion but not orthostatic hypotension.

choices.OptionStatement: A suppressed response of the baroreceptor mechanism
choices.Reason: C is correct. When a person moves from a supine to a standing position, they experience orthostatic hypotension, a fall in arterial pressure. A functional baroreceptor mechanism reacts to a drop in arterial pressure by increasing sympathetic outflow and lowering parasympathetic outflow through the vasomotor center. A resultant increase in heart rate, contractility, and total peripheral resistance (TPR) leads to increased mean systemic pressure. After a sympathectomy, the sympathetic portion of the baroreceptor system is no longer present.

choices.OptionStatement: An exaggerated response of the baroreceptor mechanism
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. An exaggerated response of the baroreceptor mechanism results in a greater inhibition of the sympathetic outflow to the peripheral vasculature, which causes vasodilation and a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old female was brought to the ER due to diarrhea, hypersalivation, and diaphoresis. While taking her history, you noted that she works at a factory that manufactures insecticides. Upon assessment, miosis was noted.  What will you give this patient?
questions.Summary: Organophosphates inhibit acetylcholinesterase in both central and sytemic nervous systems. This leads to systemic and central anticholinergic overactivation due to the build up of acetylcholine. Treatment is with the atropine, which counteracts the cholinergic effects of organophosphates.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old female is complaining of chest pain that radiates to the back and improves by leaning forward. Observation of the jugular venous waveform in this condition would reveal:
questions.Summary: Central venous pressure tracing has specific waveforms in the absense of pathology. In the presence of pathology, hallmark  findings on each wave may be present. The a wave is caused by atrial contraction; thus would be absent in atrial fibrillation. The c wave is caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve during early systole. Tricuspid regurgitation will cause a fusion of the c and v waves, with the x descent being blunted.. Right atrial relaxation causes a downward deflection on the CVP tracing, producing the x descent waveform. Rapid filling of the right atrium during late systole produces the v wave, with a subsequent y descnet as the tricuspid valve reopens.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This waveform is found in tricuspid stenosis.
B is correct. This is a case of constrictive pericarditis and the jugular venous waveform would show rapid x + y descent.
C is incorrect. A blunted y descent or a more prominent x descent would be found in cases of cardiac tamponade.
D is incorrect. An absent a wave is is characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

questions.Statement: A 29 year old patient on oral contraceptives comes in for a checkup in your clinic. She presents with severe dyspnea, tachycardia, and lower extremity tenderness. A chest x-ray is done and shows a shallow hump in the periphery of the lung. What is your next step?
questions.Summary: The treatement approach for acute PE should always consist of three major componenets: cardiopulmonary support, anticoagulation to prevent extrension and recurrence, and reperfusion of the pulmonary artery as soon as possible. Cardiopulmonary support should first be initiated with supplemental O2 and ionotropic support such as milrinone which will increase contractility of the right and left ventricle to unload the heart, however vasodilation can occur leading to hypotension. Anticoagulation, usually with heparin should be initiated as soon as PE is suspected unless patient has a strong contraindication.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This case may look like pneumonia but is actually pulmonary embolism. Pulmonary embolism is managed by a fibrinolytic.

B is incorrect.  The hump is not an actual mass but an opacity referred to as Hampton’s hump evident in pulmonary embolism. The management for pulmonary embolism is fibrinolytic therapy with heparin unless the patient is allergic or has a previous hisotry of HITT.

C is incorrect. Pulmonary embolism is not managed with bronchodilators. Bronchodilators would not benefit the patient as perfusion to the lung is compromised. This intrapulmonary shunt causes increased A-a gradient unresponsive to supplemental O2 or bornchodilators.

D is correct. This is a case of pulmonary embolism which shows a shallow, hump-shaped opacity in the lung periphery. A risk factor for pulmonary embolism is oral contraceptive use. This is managed with fibrinolytics, typically heparin, unless contraindicated due to allergy or previous history of HITT.

A 55 year old male smoker, with history of diabetes and hypertension, presents for pain in his leg that only comes up whenever he’s walking.

questions.Summary: Systolic blood pressure will increase as you move distal from the aorta and upstroke of arterial line tracing will be more drastic as you move to lower extremity due to increased vascular stiffness.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  Blood work is not specific to peripheral arterial disease. An elevation in CRP and D-dimer levels have been associated with exercise intolerance but are not diagnostic for PAD.

choices.OptionStatement: Measure the systolic pressure of the arms and legs
choices.Reason: C is correct. Taking the ankle brachial index is diagnostic for PAD which can be done in a clinic. This is done by  measuring the systolic blood pressure of the arms (brachial) and legs (dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial) and dividing the highest upper extremity value by the highest lower extremity value.

questions.Statement: A 65 year old diabetic male with a 20 pack year history of smoking seeks consult for aching pain in his leg whenever he has to take long walks. He also notes erectile dysfunction. He otherwise feels fine. What is the mechanism behind his pain?
questions.Summary: Claudication is a hallmark of peripheral arterial disease. It is manifested as pain related to exertion that improves and eventually resolves with rest. Notable risk factors include smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.

choices.OptionStatement: Imbalance between supply and demand of blood flow
choices.Reason: A is correct. The temporary ischemia of the muscles due to the supply and demand imbalance of blood flow results in cramping pain whenever the patient is walking.

choices.OptionStatement: Plaque buildup in the arterial lumen
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Although plaque build up leads to PAD eventually, this is not the mechanism behind the pain in PAD.
C is incorrect. Patients with PAD usually have sufficient collateral blood flow due to the chronicity of the disease. This is the reason why they only experience symptoms while exerting effort.

choices.OptionStatement: Venous narrowing which leads to atherosclerosis
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. The pathogenesis behind PAD is arterial, not venous, narrowing. This is also not the reason behind the pain experienced in PAD.

questions.Summary: The ABI is the first-line diagnostic test for PAD. A normal ABI ranges from 0.9 to 1.3. PAD is diagnosed with an ABI less than 0.9. Note that it may be falsely elevated with heavily calcified blood vessels.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Although a CT scan is more sensitive and specific, it is not recommended  to do a CT scan as the first step in diagnosing a patient as it is expensive and has its risks.An emergent CTA is warranted in hemodynamically stable patients but that is not the case in this question.

These mediators represent a double-edged sword: they may reduce or aggravate the harmful effects of aortic cross-clamping and unclamping. C is correct.  Blood pressure decreases during cross-clamp release due to reactive myocardial hyperemia and the vasodilator effect of myocardial stretch receptors.

questions.Statement: A 63-year-old hypertensive patient was observed to have dyspnea and bipedal edema. Upon auscultation, you noted crackles in both lung fields. What is the non-respiratory role of the lungs in regulation of blood pressure?
questions.Summary: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) is essential in the production of angiotensin II from angiotensin I, and capillary blood vessels in the lung are one of the most important sites of ACE expression and angiotensin II production in the human body.

choices.OptionStatement: Catalyzing the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II
choices.Reason: A is correct. As part of the renin-angiotensin system, the lung also plays a role in maintaining blood pressure homeostasis by catalyzing the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II via ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme), as well as maintaining acid-base homeostasis by expelling carbon dioxide.

choices.Reason: C is incorrect. This is a respiratory function of the lungs.

questions.Statement: A 58 year old chronic smoker presents for shortness of breath. On physical examination, heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 35 cpm, and blood pressure is 120/90 mm Hg. He has a lean physique with a hunched back. How does COPD affect residual volume?
questions.Summary: Expiratory airflow limitation causes increased lung volume in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Small airway walls harden as a result of COPD. Alveolar wall breakdown also contributes to airway collapse and a reduction in elastic recoil. Airway obstruction results from the thickening of the airway wall and airway collapse. Airflow restriction caused by a decrease in elastic recoil in the airway results in air entrapment and hyperinflation. Thus, the obstruction causes the patient to have trouble exhaling and an increased residual volume.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Hyperinflation of the lungs and air-trapping, a complication of COPD, results in an increased residual volume.
B is incorrect.  In COPD, the lungs are hyperinflated which causes air-trapping. This would then increase the residual volume.
C is incorrect. The residual volume would not remain the same as expiratory airflow limitation in patients with COPD will cause air-trapping hence an increase in residual volume.
D is incorrect. The majority of COPD patients will have some degree of lung hyperinflation, which leads to an increased residual volume.

questions.Summary: Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the airway radius. The medium-sized bronchi have the highest resistance since it has the smallest radius collectively and they have more branches than the smaller airways deeper in the lung.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Although smaller in size, airway resistance is lower in alveolar ducts since respiratory airways are arranged in parallel and added reciprocally.
B is incorrect. Terminal bronchioles have the lowest resistance since they collectively account for the largest radius of an airway.
C is incorrect. Resistance is inversely proportional to the radius. Primary bronchi are larger in radius which means that the airway resistance is lower than those airways deeper in the lungs.
D is correct. The medium sized bronchi collectively have the smallest radius due to more branching, leading to the the highest effective airway resistance.

questions.Statement: A 70 year old patient, chronic smoker presents for his routine checkup. In patients with emphysema, what part of the airways accounts for the highest airway resistance?
questions.Summary: Small airways, while typically offering the least resistance in healthy lungs, are the site of significantly increased resistance in some disease states such as asthma.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The trachea has the largest radius and would offer the least resistance.
B is incorrect. Resistance is inversely proportional to the radius. Primary bronchi are larger in radius which means that the airway resistance is lower than those airways deeper in the lungs.

C is correct. In diseased states, small airways have the highest resistance because they are easily occluded. Typically, airways <2 mm in diameter have the highest airway resistance in diseased states.
D is incorrect. Although the medium-sized bronchi account for the highest airway resistance in normal lungs, this is not the case in diseased states.

questions.Summary: This is a case of pulmonary embolism in which the compliance of the lungs (volume change per unit pressure change) decreases. Emboli may cause local collapse of lung tissue and decrease the compliance.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. It will be increased. In pulmonary embolism, vasoconstriction of the airways contributes to airway resistance.
B is incorrect. Because some lung areas in pulmonary embolism are ventilated but not perfused, there is an increase in alveolar dead space.
C is incorrect. Obstruction of the pulmonary vascular bed in pulmonary embolism results in poor gas exchange since the alveolar ventilation is maintained at the same level.
D is correct. Lung compliance decreases due to bronchial narrowing in the embolized part of the lung.

questions.Statement: At the age of 31 weeks, a newborn baby experienced respiratory difficulty. A chest radiograph revealed atelectasis in several regions. Which of the following best describes the dominant element of the patient's insufficient pulmonary surfactant?
questions.Summary: The main phospholipid component of mammalian surfactant and the key component responsible for reducing surface tension in the alveoli is phosphatidylcholine.

choices.Reason: A is correct.  The primary active component found in surfactant is the phospholipid, which mainly consists of Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine (Lecithin).
B is incorrect. One of the phospholipids that makes up the cell membrane is phosphatidylserine. It is crucial for cell cycle signaling, particularly in connection with apoptosis.
C is incorrect. A minor component of lung surfactant called phosphatidylinositol (PI) has the potential to take the role of phosphatidylglycerol.
D is incorrect. There is no such thing as phosphatidylpalmitate.

questions.Statement:
A 58-year-old heavy smoker presents with a productive cough as well as chronic and worsening exertional dyspnea. On auscultation, both lung fields are hyperresonant. Spirometry was done which revealed a concave-shaped maximal expiratory flow-volume (MEFV) curve. 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.Summary: Flow-volume loops are produced by asking the patient to perform maximum force inhalation to toal lung capacity then forcible and rapidly exhale to residual volume. This may reveal a characteristic pattern suggestive of a pulmonary disease. Lower airway obstruction (eg, COPD, asthma) is characterized with the effort-independent portion of the expiration curve becoming concave.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Tumors or variable intrathoracic obstruction is characterized with fattening of the expiratory curve.
B is incorrect. Restrictive lung disease is characterized with a normal shaped curve but diminished in size.
C is correct. COPD is characterized by the effort-independent portion of the expiration curve being concave.
D is incorrect.  Variable extrathoracic obstruction is characterized with flattening of the inspiratory curve, the opposite to intrathoracic obstruction.

questions.Statement: A 38-year-old obese male with a BMI of 38 is admitted in the ICU for STEMI. He was intubated on presentation for increased work of breathing. He is now on minimal ventilator settings and has passed his spontaneous breathing trial. The patient is conscious and is not in pain. After a thorough assessment, you decide to extubate the patient. Which of the following is true regarding this patient?
questions.Summary: Obesity can cause mechanical displacement of the diaphram leading to restrictive lung disease resulting in greater risks of pneumonia, prolonged mechanical ventilation, and ventilator weaning. Upper airway narrowing in the oropharynx may increase work of breathing and put these patients at a higher risk of developing post-operative acute respiratory failure.

choices.OptionStatement: Obesity can significantly decrease the work of breathing
choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  Certain conditions such as obesity, congestive heart failure, or lung diseases can significantly increase the work of breathing.

choices.OptionStatement: Spontaneous breathing trial alone is a good predictor of successful extubation
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. A spontaneous breathing trial alone cannot assess for upper airway obstruction or narrowing. Obesity can lead to failure of extubation due to increased non-sustainable work of breathing due to mechanical displacement of the diaphram and restrictive lung disease.

choices.OptionStatement: Work of breathing is higher immediately after extubation
choices.Reason: C is correct. In contrast to breathing naturally through an endotracheal tube, studies have shown that the work of breathing is higher right after extubation.

choices.OptionStatement: The work of breathing is normally measured in Watts
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. The work of breathing is normally measured in Joules

questions.Statement: Work of breathing is increased when there is an increase in resistive work. Which of the following minimizes resistive work?
questions.Summary: Resistive work refers to the work of the alveoli and tissue of the lungs which increases propotional to increases in respiratory rate. In patients with obstructive lung disease, increased respiratory rate from respiratory distress further increases the work of breathing. To decrease resistive work and overall work of breathing, increasing laminar flow, decreasing respiratory rate, and increasing airway radius can be employed.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Decreasing respiratory rate will decrease airway resistance as it is proportional to the flow rate.

B is incorrect. Decreasing the gas density would decrease the Reynolds number (an index to determine whether the flow is laminar or turbulent). Heliox (a mixture of helium and oxygen) decreases the density of inspired oxygen therefore reducing airway resistance. It has been shown to help with decreasing the work of breathing in obstructive airway diseases ie: Asthma/COPD, subglotic stenosis, laryngeal obstruction, croup, vocal cord paralysis
C is correct. Increasing the Reynold’s number will increase the gas density which will increase resistive work. Reynold's Number = (density x flow speed x linear length)/(viscosity)
D is incorrect. Increasing airway radius with bronchodilators will decrease airway resistance decreasing resistive work.

questions.Statement: A 56-year-old male presents for lung volume reduction surgery of his right lower lobe. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, COPD with emphysematous lung disease, and hypothyroidism following thyroidectomy. Which of the following endotracheal tubes would be most appropriate for this case?
questions.Summary: This patient will undergo a thoracic procedure requiring lung isolation. In thoracic surgery, Double Lumen Tubes (DLTs) are utilized to isolate the operating lung while ventilating the dependant lung. These tubes, as their name suggests, feature two distinct lumens (a bronchial lumen and tracheal lumen), each with a separate cuff and pilot balloon. Not listed as an answer choice is the neural integrity monitor (NIM) electromyogram (EMG) tracheal tube. The NIM tube is used for neck dissection cases where the laryngeal nerve requies monitoring with EMG to avoid ressection. A NIM tube would be an appropriate choice for the patient's thyroidectomy.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. These are especially used in head and neck surgery, and are designed to stay out of the operative field.

B is correct. Double lumen tubes are used in thoracic surgeries to provide lung isolation of the surgical field and one lung ventilation. Alternatively, a bronchial blocker may be placed through a traditional endotracheal tube into the bronchi of the operative lung but are often considered inferior to a double lumen tube as they are at risk for displacement from the bronchi.
C is incorrect. Reinforced endotracheal tube are mostly used in head and neck surgery where a traditional endotracheal tube may be at risk for kinking causing airway obstruction
D is incorrect. Microlaryngeal tubes are use for surgeries of the larynx for an enhanced surgical field around the vocal cords.

questions.Statement: A 23-year-old male college student arrives to the operating room after a motor vehicle accident. On physcial examination you notice facial edema and burn injuries to the face and right arm. He has mouth opening > 5cm and is a Mallampati class II. CT of the head demonstartes a Lefort II fracture. The patient has a Glascow Coma scale of 8, blood pressure is 86/41, a heart rate of 122 beats per minute, and saturating 91% on 6L via simple mask. What is your definitive management of the airway?
questions.Summary: Direct laryngoscopy and orotracheal intubation remains the best options for definitively securing the airway during an emergency/trauma.

choices.OptionStatement: Perform a rapid sequence induction and orotracheal intubation
choices.Reason: A is correct. Orotracheal intubation with rapid sequence induction and manual-inline stabilization remains the fastest and most preferred technique with sufficient mouth opening.

choices.OptionStatement: Apply one person non-invasive positive pressure ventilation
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Bag mask ventilation (BMV) in patients with facial trauma should ideally be performed using a "two-person" technique.  Non-invasive ventilation can be perfoemed to pre-oxygenate prior to intubation, however it is not a definative option to secure the airway during a trauma.

choices.OptionStatement: Use a fiberoptic scope to perform an awake orotracheal intubation
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. Fiberoptic-guided intubation is reccomended in anticipated difficult airways such as patients with limited mouth opening or Mallampati class IV. This method is impractical in patients with maxillofacial trauma as it can be time consuming and be unsuccessful due to hemorrhage and/or vomitus which can obstruct the view of the scope.

choices.OptionStatement: Secure an airway via nasotracheal intubation
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Nasotracheal intubation in patients with maxillary/basilar skull fractures risks migration of the ET tube into the skull compartment through a potential defect. Orotracheal intubation remains the technique of choice in emergencies.

questions.Statement: A 29-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being involved as a restrained passanger in a motor vehicle accident. Heart rate is 60 beats per minute and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. Glascow Coma Scale score is 9. Extremities are warm to touch. Physcial examination reveals absent sensation to bilateral upper and lower extremities. What is your next step in management of this patient's hemodynamics?
questions.Summary: This patient presents with bradycarida, hypotension, and physical exam findings consistent with neurogenic shock. Warm extremities are the result of impaired peripheral vasoconstriction. The motor and sensory deficits are suggestive of a spinal cord injury. Confirmatory testing would include radiographic evidence of vertebral column fracture. Fluid resuscitation and restoration of intravascular volume are the first line of treatment to enhance perfusion in patients with neurogenic shock. Vasopressors and ionotropic agents may be used in patients refractory to fluid resuscitation alone.

choices.OptionStatement: Transfuse 2 units of packed red blood cells.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Administration of blood products or massive transfusion protocol would be indicated in hemorrhagic shock. Hemorrhagic shock presents with hypotension and tachycardia. This patient presents with bradycardia suggestive of neurogenic shock. Volume resusitation in  neurogenic shock is best managed with crytalloid solutions such as normal saline or lactated ringer's solution.

B is incorrect. Dopamine may be used in patients presenting with cardiogenic shock or heart failure. This patient does not demostrate findings of cardiogenic shock such as jugular venous distension and peripheral edmea. Dopamine may be considered as a second line agent in neurogenic shock refractory to fluid resuscitation.

choices.OptionStatement: Initiate a 1 liter bolus of normal saline solution
choices.Reason: C is correct. The first-line management for hypotension secondary to neurogenic shock is fluid resuscitation. The majority of patients with neurogenic shock respond to intravascular volume restoration alone.

choices.OptionStatement: Administer epinephrine at a rate of 0.05 mcg/kg/min
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Vasoconstrictors can be used to enhance venous return, decrease vascular capacitance, and improve peripheral vascular tone. Administration of vasopressors such as epinephrine should only be performed after hypovolemia has been ruled out as the source of the hypotension and neurogenic shock has been identified as the likely diagnosis.

questions.Summary: In alignment with modern ERAS protocols this has given way to a more restrictive strategy of resuscitation, emphasizing a “zero-balance” approach when feasible alongside the use of dynamic markers of volume status, which may serve to better approximate losses attributable to third-spaced and insensible losses when compared to the formula-based method.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is part of the classical 4/2/1 rule and would likely lead to over resusciation.

choices.OptionStatement: Use the 4/2/1 rule for fluid resuscitation
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. This is a classic and conventional method of resuscitation and has been criticized in recent years for a tendency to over resuscitate which is associated with increased morbidity.

choices.OptionStatement: Use the zero-balance approach in fluid resuscitation
choices.Reason: C is correct. A more restrictive approach in resuscitation has been gaining popularity in recent years as it may better approximate losses with the use of dynamic markers of volume status.
D is incorrect. No conclusive research has shown that using colloid solutions reduces mortality in hypovolemic shock.

questions.References: Fatakia A, Winters R, Amedee RG. Epistaxis: a common problem. Ochsner J. 2010; 10:176-178.
questions.Statement: You did nasotracheal intubation on a 30 year old patient scheduled for mandibulotomy and noted epistaxis. What is your next step?
questions.Summary: Epistaxis is a common complication of nasotracheal intubation. The best decision would be to proceed with the intubation and complete it in order to tamponade the bleeding.

choices.OptionStatement: Withdraw the tube and reinsert on the other side
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Mild epistaxis usually resolves spontaneously and intubation should be completed in order to tamponade the bleeding and protect the airway.

choices.OptionStatement: Withdraw the tube and insert via oropharynx
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. The patient is scheduled for an oropharyngeal surgery so an oropharyngeal airway is not feasible.
C is correct. Bleeding is a common complication that happens with nasal intubation and usually resolves spontaneously. Completing the intubation would be wise to tamponade the bleeding.
D is incorrect. Mild epistaxis usually resolves spontaneously; withholding intubation would mean your patient will not have a secure airway during the surgery.

questions.Statement: A 15 year old patient underwent appendectomy a few hours ago. She is now back in her room resting. When she woke up, she complained that she couldn’t see and noted pain whenever she tried to blink. What is the management of this patient?
questions.Summary: Corneal abrasion is the most common ocular complication of general anesthesia. Its treatment includes application of artificial tears, topical antibiotic ointment, and patching the injured eye shut.

choices.OptionStatement: Reassure the patient that this is temporary
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This history is suggestive of corneal abrasion which is the most common ocular complication of general anesthesia. Aggressive treatment early on is advised as permanent injury is possible.

choices.OptionStatement: Apply artificial tears and patch the injured eye(s)
choices.Reason: B is correct. Treatment of corneal abrasion consists of artificial tears, prophylactic topical antibiotic ointment and patching the injured eye(s) shut.

C is incorrect. Acetazolamide is a diuretic and a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor commonly used to treat motion sickness and glaucoma. This can also be used in ischemic optic neuropathy but not as a definitive treatment.
D is incorrect. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that may be used in ischemic optic neuropathy not in corneal abrasion.

questions.Statement: A 25 year old parturient came was in labor for 12 hours and was advised for cesarian section. 12 hours after the procedure,  the patient complained of not being able to see. questions.Summary: Cortical blindness has been observed following procedures such as cardiac surgery, craniotomy, laryngectomy, and Cesarean section. Air or particle emboli during cardiopulmonary bypass may possibly be the cause. Loss of vision but continued pupillary responses to light are characteristics of cortical blindness. An examination of the fundus is often normal. This is confirmed with CT or MRI of the parietal or occipital lobes.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is a case of cortical blindness and can be confirmed via CT scan or MRI of the parietal or occipital lobes.
B is incorrect.  This is a case of cortical blindness and can be confirmed via CT scan or MRI of the parietal or occipital lobes.
C is correct. Cortical blindness is confirmed via CT scan or MRI of the parietal or occipital lobes.

choices.OptionStatement: CT scan of the temporal lobe
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. This is a case of cortical blindness and can be confirmed via CT scan or MRI of the parietal or occipital lobes.

questions.Statement: A 23 year old parturient is in the second stage of labor and has just received an epidural catheter. What is an appropriate dosage of analgesic to administer via the catheter?
questions.Summary: Block initiation is the process during which the epidural block is established at a level that provides adequate pain relief. This is accomplished by bolus dosing of the catheter.  The total bolus dose is usually 10-20 ml of dilute local anesthetic, with or without narcotic, injected in 5 ml increments every 5-10 minutes. Adding 50-100 mcg of fentanyl into the epidural during initiation of the epidural can increase patient comfort and supplement the effect of the local anesthetic but comes with the risk of pruritis and nausea.

choices.OptionStatement: 15 ml of dilute local anesthetic injected in one bolus
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Block initiation is usually given in bolus doses of 10-20 ml of dilute local anesthetic injected in 5 ml increments every 5-10 minutes.

choices.OptionStatement: 5 ml of dilute local anesthetic with narcotic injected every 5 minutes for four times
choices.Reason: B is correct. Block initiation is given in bolus dosing. The total bolus dose is usually 10-20 ml of dilute local anesthetic, with or without narcotic, injected in 5 ml increments every 5-10 minutes.

C is incorrect. Administration of a narcotic only solution for epidural analgesia is unlikely to confer adequate or lasting analgesia. However, narcotics may be added to dilute local anesthetic solution.

choices.OptionStatement: 10-20 ml of dilute local anesthetic in one bolus
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Block initiation is usually given in bolus doses of 10-20 ml of dilute local anesthetic injected in 5 ml increments every 5-10 minutes.

questions.Summary: The results of studies utilizing ropivacaine for cesarean sections suggest that its use is better when paired with an opioid. Ropivacaine is less potent than bupivacaine and has a slightly shorter duration of action, but offers the advantage of having a quicker recovery of motor function.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Bupivacaine is frequently the drug of choice in caesarian sections but tends to last longer than the other choices provided.

C is incorrect. Chloroprocraine is rarely used in spinal anesthesia for c-section due to its shorter duration of action and increased risk of transient neurologic symptoms.

questions.Statement: You are preparing a parturient for spinal anesthesia undergoing Cesarean delivery. After induction, the patient’s blood pressure suddenly drops from 120/80 mmHg to 90/60 mmHg. What is your next step in management?
questions.Summary: Neuraxial techniques cause a sympathectomy which in turn reduces systemic vascular resistance, venous return, and blood pressure. Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 130/80, heart rate 105, respiratory rate 24. The total body surface area affected is 25%. The estimated fluid required for the first 8 hours is:
questions.Summary: Fluid resuscitation is guided by formulas that estimate initial fluid requirements based on burn severity and body weight and provide an initial starting point for resuscitation. For the first 24 hours after burn injury, fluid resuscitation is estimated using the Parkland formula. Patients receive Lactated Ringer’s solution, 4 mL/kg per percentage of burned surface area, within the first 24 hours. Half of this calculated volume is administered within the first 8 hours, the second half is administered during the following 16 hours.  Continuous clinical assessment of hemodynamics and urine output guide ongoing fluid resuscitation.

questions.Statement: After experiencing full thickness burns in multiple areas of his body, a 30 -year-old 60 kg male is assessed in the emergency department. The affected body parts include his face, anterior torso, and right lower extremity. What is the best estimate of fluid administration per hour for the first 8 hours?
questions.Summary: The Parkland formula: 4cc/kg x patient weight (kg) x percent body surface area is used to estimate initial volume resuscitation of burn patients in the first 24 hours following injury. Total body surface area is estimated using the "Wallace Rule of 9s", as each body part is assigned a predetermined percentage. Head (front and back) = 9%, anterior torso = 18%, posterior torso = 18%, each arm = 9%, each leg = 18%, genitalia = 1%.   In this patient estimated surface area is as follows: face = 4.5%, anterior torso = 18%, right leg = 18% for a total of 40.5%.

choices.Reason:
A is incorrect. The Parkland formula is often used to calculate fluid resuscitation requirements in burn victims. The volume of crystalloid required is calculated as 4 milliliters x body weight (kg) x % TBSA (total body surface area burned).

A 60 kg person with burns affecting the face (4.5%), anterior torso (18%), and one leg (18%) would require a total of 4 x 60 x 40.5 = 9,720 ml of crystalloid to be administered over the next 24 hours. Half of the total volume (4,860 ml) is administered over the first 8 hours and the other half over the following 16 hours.

B is incorrect. The Parkland formula is often used to calculate fluid resuscitation requirements in burn victims. The volume of crystalloid required is calculated as 4 milliliters x body weight (kg) x % TBSA (total body surface area burned).

A 60 kg person with burns affecting the face (4.5%), anterior torso (18%), and one leg (18%) would require a total of 4 x 60 x 40.5 = 9,720 ml of crystalloid to be administered over the next 24 hours. Half of the total volume (4,860 ml) is administered over the first 8 hours and the other half over the following 16 hours.
C is correct. 4,860 ml is the volume to be delivered in the first 8 hours: 4,860/8 = 607.5 ml/hr.
D is incorrect. The volume to be administered over the second portion of the resuscitation (the 16 hours following the initial 8 hours) is 4,860 ml: 4,860/16 = 303.75 ml/hr.

questions.Statement: A 20-year-old 50 kg female is in the ICU being treated for burns covering 30% of her total body surface area (TBSA). On the 4th day of admission, she develops progressive dyspnea, increased work of breathing and stridor. A decison is made to intubate the patient emergently. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.Summary: Succinylcholine is safe to use in patients with burn injuries within the first 24 hours of the event. After this time, administration can cause transient life-threatening hyperkalemia that may lead to cardiac arrest.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. As a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, Pancuronium is safe to use in burn patients however studies have shown unusual resistance to pancuronium in severe burns.
B is incorrect. As a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, Rocuronium is safe to use in burn patients and is the preferred drug to provide rapid onset of paralysis and superior intubating conditions.
C is incorrect. As a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, Cisatricurium is safe to use in burn patients.

D is correct. Patients with burn injuries develop an upregulation of extrajuntional acetylcholine receptor after injury. When succinylcholine is administered after 24 hours after a burn, activation of acetylcholine receptors cause a transient increase in extracelluar potassium that can lead to life-threatening hyperkalemia and cardiac arrest.

questions.Statement: You are called to evaluate a fever in a 34-year-old male. He has a past medical history of longstanding depression and a recent hospitalization 2 weeks ago for schizophrenia. He has been on a stable dose of sertraline for years and was recently started on haloperidol after discharge from the most recent admission. He is cooperative with the exam, however he is unable to appropriately identify where he is or which year it is. Vital signs are as follows:  Temperature 39 deg C, Blood pressure 160/120, Heart rate 120, Respiratory rate 22. What is the most definitive management of this condition?
questions.Summary: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome presents with fever, muscle rigidity, altered mental status (confusion, anxiety, agitation), and autonomic dysfunction (tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, urinary incontinence/retention, sialorrhea) and typically presents 1-2 weeks after initiation of antipsychotic medication. The management of NMS consistents of supportive care but it is imperative to discontinue the offending agent (in this case haloperidol). Failure to discontinue recently started antipsychotics will cuase progression of NMS to rhabdomyolysis which can lead to renal failure.

choices.Reason: A is correct. This patient presents with fever, muscle rigidity, hypertension, altered mental status, and recent initiation of a new antipsychotic medication consistent of neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Cessation of causative agents is the first-line management.
B is incorrect. Observation of this would delay the management. Failure to identify and treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome may lead to rhabdomylosis and renal failure.

C is incorrect. Benzodiazapines and other pharmacologic therapy (dentrolene, bromocriptine, amantadine) can be used for neuropsychiatric symptoms of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS). These treatments may help with synptomatology, however they will not definitively treat the condition. Without discontinuing the offending agent, NMS can progress to to more serious sequelae.
D is incorrect. Applying cooling blankets may help in reducing the fever in aptients with NMS, however they will not treat the underlying cause.

questions.Statement: A patient presents after cystoscopy with ureteral stent placement with a temperature of 39.4 deg C, blood pressure of 84/58, heart rate 122 bpm, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths pre minute. Laboratory values show a leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation. The patient continues to be hypotensive after appropriate initial resusitation with crystalloid solution. What is the next step in management?
questions.Summary: This patient presents with fever, leukocytosis, and hypotension with a possible source of infection (due to the recent cystoscopy and stent placement) which is consistent with a diagnosis of sepsis. Hypotension refractory to initial fluid resusitation is consistent with septic shock and requires vasopressor therapy. According to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, the first choice of vasopressor in septic shock is norepinephrine.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This patient presents with fever, leukocytosis, and hypotension with a possible source of infection (due to the recent cystoscopy and stent placement) which is consistent with a diagnosis of sepsis. Hypotension refractory to initial fluid resusitation is consistent with septic shock and requires vasopressor therapy. Sepsis in itself is not an indication for intubation and mechanical ventilation as the patient is breathing spontaneously and appropriately compensating the lactic accidosis associated with sepsis.

B is incorrect. Vasopressor therapy is not indicated as the next treatment modality in sepsis that is refractory to fluid resusitation. Numerous studies reviewed by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign have found vasopressin to be deficient in septic patients, however these studies have failed to to show statistical significance. It can be used as an adjuct for hypotension refractory to first line vasopressors.

C is correct. According to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, norepinephrine remains the first line vasopressor of choice used in septic shock.  Numerous trials have demonstarted its superiority compared to dopamine and vasopressin.

D is incorrect. The most recent Surviving Sepsis Campaign Guidelines reccomend initial resusitation fluid challenge of either Crytalloid 1000cc or Colloid 300-500cc within the first hour of identifying a patient with sepsis. Most recent guidleines have failed to show a clear benefit to using crystalloid over colloid. In this patient, hypotension has been refractory to initial fluid resusitation indicating the need to initiate vasopressor therpy.

questions.Statement: A 67-year-old patient is in the SICU 4 hours after undergoing coronary artery bypass graft secondary to triple vessel ischemic heart disease. The patient’s blood pressure remains in the 80s/50s mmHg while on epinephrine, norepinephrine, and vasopressin. Point of care ultrasound and intraoperative TEE demonsrate adequate fluid resuscitation. There is limited drainage from the mediastinal chest tube and no evidence of cardiac tamponade. What is your next step in the management of this patient?
questions.Summary: Vasoplegic shock commonly presents following cardiac surgery where cardiopulmonary bypass is utilized. Depletion of endogenous catecholamines results in an excessive loss of vascular muscle tone and hypotension refractory to vasopressor therapy. Methylene blue can be used when hypotension is refractory to vasopressor use. It binds guanylate cyclase and inhibits cyclic guanosine monophosphate in the vascular smooth muscle, further inhibting  the effects of nitric oxide and other vasodilators in the endothelium and vascular smooth muscle.

choices.Reason: A is correct. This patient presents with hypotension following cardaic revascularization that is refractory to initial vasporessor therapy. Other causes such and hypovolemia and cardaic tamponade have been ruled out. The most likely diagnosis is vasoplegic shock. Methylene blue has been shown to be effective in vasoplegia following cardiopulmonary bypass that is refractory to vassopressors. Methylene blue acts by  binding guanylate cyclase and inhibiting cyclic guanosine monophosphate in the vascular smooth muscle. This mechanism inhibits the effects of nitric oxide and other vasodilators in the endothelium and vascular smooth muscle leading to increased total peripheral resistance and increasd blood pressure.

B is incorrect. Vasopressin is generally a non-titratable vassopressor and increasing the dose beyond its reccomended dose range is not reccomended. The need for escalation of vassopressors is associated with increased morbidity and mortality.

choices.OptionStatement: Begin fluid resusitation with a startch colloid solution
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. Synthetic colloids (starches) have a higher incidence of compromised renal function than crystalloids and only marginally lower resuscitation volume requirements despite their volume expansion/retention capabilities. Given this patient appears to be adequately volume resusitated, vasoplegic shock is the more likely diagnosis.

choices.OptionStatement: Return to the operating room for exploration
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. The patient presentation of vasoplegia can be managed non-surgically. Surgical re-exloration would be indicated for mediastinal bleeding.

questions.Statement: A 65-year-old patient is admitted in the ICU for 2 weeks for advanced cirrhosis. Upon assessment, you noted worsening of jaundice and bipedal pitting edema. You ordered serum albumin and the results revealed hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following diuretics will have increased free fraction concentration in the plasma?
questions.Summary: Albumin is a major drug-binding protein that influences the available free fraction of certain drugs within the plasma. Drugs that are highly bound by plasma proteins are influenced by hyopalbuminemia. Decreased serum albumin causes an increase in free fraction of such drugs to exert there effect on the body. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is highly bound to albumin and hypoalbuminemia will cause increased free fraction of the drug.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Hypoalbuminemia occurs in advanced liver disease due to decreased synthetic function. Drugs transported by albumin will have increased plasma concentrations due to decreased binding sites. Furosemide is transported by albumin.
B is incorrect. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is not transported by albumin; therefore decreases in serum albumin will not affect serum mannitol levels.

C is incorrect. Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist and a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is not transported by albumin; therefore decreases in serum albumin will not affect serum aldosterone levels.
D is incorrect. Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that is not transported by albumin. Changes in serum albumin will not affect serum hydrochlorothiazide levels.

questions.Statement: A 58-year-old female smoker with a history of hypertension and COPD is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy at an outpatient surgery center. Her COPD is controlled on a fluticasone inhaler. During her last surgery, she had persistant severe nausea and vomiting after discharge and required re-hospitalization on post-op day 1. Which of the follow agents would be most appropriate for maintainence of general anesthesia?
questions.Summary: In general anesthesia, total intravenous anesthesia is the preferred technique for adults with a history of severe post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV). It provides fast emergence and a safe choice for patients with problems with ventilation and lung perfusion due to its bronhcodilator properties.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Sevoflurane is a volatile anesthetic delivered by inhalation of vaporized gases. Although volitile anesthetics are potent bronchodilors, they are associated with post-operative nausea and vomiting after maintainence of general anesthesia. Although sevoflurane is one of the most common agents for maintainence of general anesthesia, it would not be the best choice in this patient with a history of severe post-op nausea and vomiting.

B is incorrect. Desflurane is a volatile anesthetic associated witha rapid onset and emergence from general anesthesia.  Although volitile anesthetics are potent bronchodilors, desflurane is associated with increased airway reactivity as compared to sevoflurane. As a volitile anesthetic, desflurane does not reduce the risk of PONV after general anesthesia.

C is incorrect. Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that promotes bronchodialtion, however it is generally used as an adjuct rather than maintence of general anesthesia. The use of ketamine does not reduce the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting, despite being a reasonable option for its bronchodilator propreties in this patient with COPD.

D is correct. Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that can be used for both sedation and maintence of general anesthesia. In this patient with severe PONV, Propofol would be the best choice as it has antimimetic properties. Total intravenous anesthetic (TIVA) with propofol is associated with decreased risk and severity of PONV after general anesthesia.

questions.Statement: An 8-year-old is scheduled for tonsillectomy. On his way into the hospital, the parents had to carry the patient while he was throwing tantrums. His vital signs are stable in the preoperative area. How will you induce anesthesia in this patient?
questions.Summary: Inhaled induction is the preffered method of induction of anesthesia in the pediatric population. Children are often uncooperative with the painful placement of intravenous access in the pre-operative area, which limits the methods of induction with IV agents.  Inhaled induction provides minimal painful stimuli and a less traumatic event for children and can be supplemented with an oral or nasal anxiolytic before surgery.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Total intravenous anesthesia is a technique for general anesthesia achieved by intravenous anesthesics without the use of inhaled anesthestics. Although it has many benefits, it is not recommended in pediatric patients as it requires placement of an IV prior to induction.

B is correct. Inhalation induction anesthesia is achieved by inhalation of volatile anesthetics. This may be the most appropriate choice in the pediatric population as it it not painful and IV access is not required for induction. Intravenous access is often obtained after induction of anesthesia as the patient does not respond to the painful stimuli.

C is incorrect. Neuroleptanesthesia is the combination of an opioid with a neuroleptic agent (antipsychotic medication) to produce sedation and analgesia, tranquility, immobility, and amnesia. It is not commonly recommended for children as IV access is required for titration.

D is incorrect. Balanced anesthesia is a technique for maintence of anesthesia which utilizes multiple agents of different medication classes. This is still not suitable for the induction of anesthsia in children as it involves intravenous anesthetics, however it would be an appropriate technique for anesthetic maintence.

questions.Statement: Which of the following anesthesthetic techniques would you avoid in a patient with Parkinson's disease?
questions.Summary: Neuroleptanesthesia is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease due to the disruption of dopamine balance in most neuroleptic agents.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Balanced anesthesia has a low side effect profile due to utilizing multiple agents at lower dosages and targetting different receptors.

B is correct. Neuroleptanesthesia is the combination of an opioid with a neuroleptic/antipsychotic agent to produce sedation and analgesia, tranquility, immobility, and amnesia. It is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease since butyrophenones interrupt dopamine balance.
C is incorrect. Volatile induction and maintenance anesthesia is achieved by inhalation of potent volatile anesthetics. It is not contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease.

D is incorrect. Total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) used for general anesthesia is both achieved and maintained by intravenous hypnotics in the form of boluses or continuous infusion. It is not contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease.

questions.Statement: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department after experiencing chest pain for the past two hours. He has a history of hypertension for which he is non-compliant with therapy. An acute myocardial infarction of the anterior wall is confirmed by cardiac markers and ECG. Presently, the patient's vital signs are within normal ranges, but angina persists. The following should be given except:
questions.Summary: The use of NSAIDs has been linked to an increased risk of ischemic events and bleeding following acute myocardial infarction. NSAIDs are associated with an increased risk MI and perioperative mortality. This association was prevalent in patients with pre-existing coronary artery disease (CAD). NSAIDs that carried the highest risk for MI and perioperative mortality were include diclofenac and ibuprofen.

choices.Reason: A is not the exemption. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor which is beneficial in post myocardial infarctions by preventing cardiac remodeling. Most studies show initiation of an ACE inhibitor within the first 24 hours to 16 days improves Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF) at one year.
B is not the exemption. Initiation of a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) after acute myocardial infarction has been shown to reduce infarct size and early morbidity if started early and continued long term.

C is not the exemption. Statin therapy (atorvastatin) is reccomended in all patients with acute myocardial infarction. Statins are thought to stabilize the atheromatous plaque and decrease Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACE).

D is correct. Ibuprofen is an NSAID which is contraindicated in acute myocardial infarction.The use of NSAIDs has been linked to an increased risk of ischemic events and bleeding following a myocardial infarction.

questions.Summary: NSAIDs are avoided in patients with heart failure due to an increased risk of fluid retention and elevated blood pressure.

choices.Reason: A is correct. This patient presents with symptoms consistent with congestive heart failure (dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity pitting edema, pulmonary congestion). NSAIDs are avoided in patients with heart failure due to the risk of increased blood pressure and fluid retention.
B is incorrect. Acetaminophen is considered safer than NSAIDs in patients with heart failure and do not carry the risk of increased blood pressure and fluid retention.
C is incorrect. Paracetamol is another name for acetaminophen and is considered safe for patients with congestive heart failure.
D is incorrect. Aspirin is useful and advised in many disorders that frequently coexist with heart failure, however there is no universal agreement on its usage in individuals with heart failure.

questions.Statement: According to studies on pain perception, which of the following statements has the most evidence of support?
questions.Summary: Experimental studies have confirmed what clinical providers have known for a long time: attention and awareness affect pain perception. Studies have conclusively shown that psychological factors influence pain perception.

choices.OptionStatement: A stranger present during a painful procedure increases pain
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The presence of a stranger decreases pain related arousal, while the presence of a significant other increases facial expression of pain.

choices.OptionStatement: Patients’ expectations about a potentially painful experience will affect pain perception.

questions.Statement: In regards to pain experience and perception and its relationship with gender, which of the following is most true?
questions.Summary: Differences in pain experience and pain perception has been shown to be related to the differences in sex and gender roles.

choices.OptionStatement: Individuals with higher masculinity scores show a decreased pain tolerance than those with higher femininity scores.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Individuals with high masculinity scores showed higher pain tolerance and individuals with high femininity scores showed higher pain sensitivity.

choices.OptionStatement: One’s perception of their own gender and gender roles is not associated with pain perception.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. One's perception of their own gender and gender role has a great deal of influence on their pain perception.

choices.OptionStatement: Individuals of the female gender experience more pain than individuals of the male gender.
choices.Reason: C is correct. Individuals of the female gender experience more pain than those of the male gender due to a higher burden of disease or conditions that cause pain.

choices.OptionStatement: Individuals of the male gender experience a greater prevalence of some painful conditions, such as work-related trauma and cancer.
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Research has shown that individuals of the male gender experience a greater prevalence of some painful conditions, however these include conditions such as duodenal ulcers and Buerger’s disease.

questions.Statement: Which of the following physiologic changes is a consequence of aging?
questions.Summary: As one ages, there is a decrease in lean muscle mass and increased deposition of ectopic fat that changes body compsition. These factors influence the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of medications through changes in: volume of distribution, renal impairment, and decreased hepatic function. This leads to decreased elimination of both lipid and water souble medicaitons and as a result increased peak plasma concentrations.

choices.OptionStatement: Decreased total body fat and total body water
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Aging leads to an increase in total body fat and a decrease in total body water. After the age of 30, there is a decrease in lean muscle mass and ectopic fat infiltration that changes body composition.

choices.OptionStatement: Decreased peak plasma concentrations of water-soluble drugs
choices.Reason: B is incorrect.  Aging leads to higher peak plasma concentrations of water-soluble drugs
C is incorrect. There is decreased elimination of lipid-soluble drugs due to decreased total body water and increased total body fat.
D is correct. Older adults have altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics that leads to changes in drug metabolism and elimination.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Practice-based learning and improvement is a core competency which refers to the candidate’s ability to investigate and evaluate patient care practices
B is incorrect. Surgical skills are not a core competency integral to quality patient care.

C is incorrect. Medical knowledge, not medical expertise is a core competency. Candidates are to demonstrate knowledge about established and evolving biomedical, clinical, and cognate sciences; as well as the application of these sciences in patient care.
D is incorrect. Specialized practice is not a core competency.

questions.Statement: According to The American Board of Medical Specialties (ABMS), which of the following is a demonstartion of the Professionalism competency?
questions.Summary: As outlined by The American Board of Medical Specialties, the Professionalism competency refers to the candidate’s demonstration of a commitment to carrying out professional responsibilities. These include: 1. Adhering to ethical principles; 2. Applying skills and value to deliver compassionate, patient-centered care; 3. Demonstrating humanism; 4. Being sensitive to diverse patient populations and workforce; and 5. Practicing wellness and self-care.

choices.OptionStatement: Commitment to carrying out medical responsibilities
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Commitment to carrying out professional responsibilities is part of demonstarting professionalism. Medical responsibilities are not covered under the professionalism competency.
B is incorrect. Professionalism is a demonstration of adherence to ethical principles. Medical principles are not covered under the professionalism competency
C is correct. The practice of wellness and self-care are considered a demonstartion of professionalism under the competencies outlined by The American Board of Medical Specialties (ABMS)
D is incorrect. Patient-centered care is a demonstartion of professionalism outlined by the ABMS, Practice-centered care is not.
