questions.Statement: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding  answering multiple-choice questions?
questions.Summary: There are a number of strategies to avoid errors when taking multiple-choice tests. A clear understanding of the question is imperative before proceeding to the answer section; the mind is generally the clearest immediately after reading the question.

choices.OptionStatement: Answers that include "Always", "Never", "Must", and "All" are generally wrong. Answers that include "Seldom", "Generally", "Probably", and "Usually" are generally correct.
choices.Reason: A is correct. Answers that include "Always", "Never", "Must", and "All" are generally wrong. Answers that include "Seldom", "Generally", "Probably", and "Usually" are generally correct.

choices.OptionStatement: When answers are divided into categories, if a choice does not have a relationship to the others, it is probably right.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. When answers are divided into categories, if a choice does not have a relationship to the others, it is probably "wrong"

choices.OptionStatement: Questions are usually written at an attempt to "trick" the examinee in order to make them think crtitically.
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. Board examination questions are not written with the intent to "trick" the examinee. If an examinee believes the question is trying to "trick" them, they are likely overthinking the question.

choices.OptionStatement: When unsure of an answer choice, always choose the shortest of the answers.
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. When making an uninformed guess, it is likely that the longest of the answers is correct.  Test writers are required to make questions unquestionably correct, which often results in a longer explaination to the answer choice.

questions.Keywords: Tolerance, Tachyphylaxis, Desensitization, Pharmacodynamic Tolerance, Pharmacokinetic Tolerance, Down Regulation
questions.References: Mitra S, Sinatra RS. Perioperative management of acute pain in the opioid-dependent patient. Anesthesiology 2004; 101:212-227.
questions.Statement: The use of chronic opioids leads to a decrease in drug response as a result of decereased substrates available for receptor activation. This is known as:
questions.Summary: Tolerance is defined as the progressive diminished response to a drug at a certain dose following repeated exposure, and thus requiring increased dosage on subsequent administrations to achieve the same effect. It is a state of adaptation in which exposure to a certain dose of a drug for long duration of time leads to diminished drug effects.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Tachyphylaxis is the appearance of progressive decrease in response to a given dose after repetitive administration of a pharmacologically or physiologically active substance, however it is observed in the acute setting and sometimes within one dose rather than over a long period of time.

B is incorrect.  Drug resistance is seen in the use of antibiotics and antimalarials due to 1. inadequate compliance with treatment regimens, 2. poor dosing, 3. lack of infection control; which lead to the spread of resistant organisms.

C is correct.  Tolerance is a common phenomenon observed with prolonged use of all opioid agonists. Tolerance is defined as a state of adaptation in which exposure to a certain dose of a drug for a long duration of time leads to diminished drug effects. Over time, patients will require increased dosing to achieve the same effect.

D is incorrect. Drug dependence is defined as a state of maladaptation in which an individual will experience withdrawal symptoms if they stop or decrease the dose of a drug that has been used chronically.

questions.Keywords: Tolerance, Tachyphylaxis, Desensitization, Pharmacodynamic Tolerance, Pharmacokinetic Tolerance, Down Regulation
questions.References: Mitra S, Sinatra RS. Perioperative management of acute pain in the opioid-dependent patient. Anesthesiology 2004; 101:212-227.
questions.Statement: A 50 year old patient has been taking Vicodin whenever he feels pain in his knee. He verbalized he can finish a bottle every 2-3 weeks. Lately, he complained he needs to take twice as much for pain relief.  What is the mechanism behind this condition?
questions.Summary: Opioid tolerance occurs due to neuroadaptive changes at the receptor level in forms of receptor desensitization and down regulation of the number of receptors on the cell membrane.

choices.OptionStatement: Receptor desensitization and down-regulation of the number of receptors
choices.Reason: A is correct.  Neuroadaptive changes at the receptor level in forms of receptor desensitization and down-regulation of the number of receptors on the cell membrane is a widely accepted theory for the development of opioid tolerance.
B is incorrect. This is true of tachyphylaxis not tolerance.
C is incorrect. This is a mechanism of dobutamine tolerance not opioid tolerance.

D is incorrect. This is true of tachyphylaxis not tolerance. Resistance to the hypotensive effect of sodium nitroprusside (SNP) may reflect tachyphylaxis to the drug due to cyanide toxicity or secondary to an increase in plasma renin activity.

questions.References: Becker DE, Rosenberg M. Nitrous oxide and the inhalation anesthetics. Anesth Prog. 2008 Winter;55(4):124-30; quiz 131-2. doi: 10.2344/0003-3006-55.4.124. PMID: 19108597; PMCID: PMC2614651.
questions.Statement: Among the inhaled anesthetics, this exists as a gas at standard temperature and pressure. Which of the following descriptions is most true?
questions.Summary: Nitrous oxide is unique in which it exists as a gas at standard temperature and pressure. It has the least potency and the highest MAC among other inhaled anesthetics.

choices.OptionStatement: It is the least potent and has the highest MAC
choices.Reason: A is correct. The question describes nitrous oxide which is unique in that it exists as a gas at standard temperature and pressure. It has the least potency and the highest MAC.

choices.OptionStatement: It is the most potent and has the lowest MAC
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Nitrous oxide is not the most potent inhaled anesthetic but Isoflurane is. It also does not have the lowest MAC.

choices.OptionStatement: It has intermediate potency and the highest MAC
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. Nitrous oxide has a low potency.

choices.OptionStatement: It is the most potent and has the highest MAC
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Nitrous oxide is not the most potent inhaled anesthetic although it does have the highest MAC.

questions.References: Hawkley TF, Preston M, Maani CV. Isoflurane. [Updated 2022 Aug 15]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2022 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532957/
questions.Statement: A 30 year old patient is scheduled for ORIF and requested general anesthesia via inhalation as he is scared of needles. He also expressed concerns of financial difficulties and wanted an anesthetic that is cost-effective. You think of an inhaled anesthetic which fits your patient’s description but has a slow onset and is highly pungent which may cause coughing. What is the described anesthetic?
questions.Summary: Isoflurane is an inhaled anesthetic agent with a slow onset, making it a less than ideal choice for inducing anesthesia.  It is highly pungent and may cause coughing, breath-holding, or laryngospasm, as well as mildly increased secretions.  Given its high potency and low cost, isoflurane may be a cost-effective option for long surgeries

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Desflurane has a similar hemodynamic profile to isoflurane, but has a more rapid onset and recovery. Desflurane is extremely noxious and cannot be used for induction due to intense airway irritation and transient sympathetic stimulation.

B is correct.  The official labeling indicates isoflurane may be used for induction of anesthesia, but it is highly pungent and may cause coughing, breath-holding, or laryngospasm, as well as mildly increased secretions.  Given its high potency and low cost, isoflurane may be a cost-effective option for long surgeries. Isoflurane also has a slower onset than sevoflurane, so is not an optimal choice for induction.

C is incorrect. Enflurane is no longer used in the United States due to the availability of newer agents. It has a slow onset and recovery and can cause myocardial depression. Enflurane can also cause frank seizures and renal toxicity.

D is incorrect.  Halothane is no longer used in the United States due to the availability of newer agents. It has a slow onset and recovery and can cause myocardial depression. Halothane can cause hepatotoxicity and increases the risk of arrhythmias due to increased sensitivity to catecholamines.

questions.Keywords: Induction, maintenance, nitrous oxide, sevoflurane, isoflurane, desflurane, minimum alveolar concentration, recovery time
questions.References: Eilers H, Yost S. General anesthetics. In: Katzung BG, ed. Basic & Clinical Pharmacology. 14th ed. McGraw-Hill; Accessed August 30, 2020. https://accessmedicine-mhmedical-com.ezproxy.library.wisc.edu/content.aspx?bookid=2249&sectionid=175220393
questions.Statement: A 20 year old college student who is asthmatic, was scheduled for appendectomy. After induction of the volatile anesthetic, there was an increase in peak air pressure and prolonged expiration. Which of the following anesthetics most likely caused this?
questions.Summary: Desflurane is extremely noxious and cannot be used for induction of anesthesia due to intense airway irritation and transient sympathetic stimulation

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Halothane is no longer available in the US and could not have been used in this situation as halothane is odorless making it less prone to cause bronchospasm.
B is incorrect. Sevoflurane features a rapid onset and low pungency; this makes it appropriate for induction of anesthesia. This also makes it unlikely to cause bronchospasm.
C is correct. This is the most likely cause of the increase in peak airway pressure and prolonged expiration as desflurane is very pungent which causes bronchospasm.

D is incorrect.  nitrous oxide does not produce full surgical anesthesia even if the patient were breathing pure nitrous oxide, so it must be combined with other anesthetics if complete sedation is required. It is also nonpungent making it unlikely to cause bronchospasm.

questions.Keywords: Seizure, Postoperative delirium, Delayed emergence, Serotonin Syndrome, Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome, Malignant Hyperthermia
questions.References: Rabinstein AA, Keegan MT. Neurologic complications of anesthesia: A practical approach. Neurol Clin Pract. 2013 Aug;3(4):295-304. doi: 10.1212/CPJ.0b013e3182a1b9bd. PMID: 29473613; PMCID: PMC5765958.
questions.Statement: A 40 year old patient presented for emergent appendectomy. She takes Diazepam sometimes for anxiety whenever she feels stressed at work. After the procedure, the patient was shouting at the wall and looked severely agitated. What is your management?
questions.Summary: Postoperative delirium is a fairly frequent complication in certain populations (elderly, polypharmacy-specifically benzodiazepine prescribed patients, and patients with preexisting cognitive impairment). These patients should be managed with dexmedetomidine and an antidopamingergic drug. Benzodiazepines have been associated with higher levels of postoperative delirium and should be avoided.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  It has been shown that postoperative use of benzodiazepines is associated with higher levels of postoperative delirium and should be avoided.

B is correct. Patients experiencing postoperative delirium may require sedation due to agitation; dexmedetomidine is recommended for sedation and antidopaminergic drugs are first line choice for agitation in this group.
C is incorrect. Patients who are experiencing postoperative delirium should be sedated before managing agitation.
D is incorrect. Clorazepate should not be given in a patient experiencing postoperative delirium as benzodiazepines may exacerbate the symptoms.

questions.Keywords: Seizure, Postoperative delirium, Delayed emergence, Serotonin Syndrome, Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome, Malignant Hyperthermia
questions.References: Volpi-Abadie J, Kaye AM, Kaye AD. Serotonin syndrome. Ochsner J. 2013 Winter;13(4):533-40. PMID: 24358002; PMCID: PMC3865832.
questions.Statement: A 38 year old patient on Fluoxetine complained of RUQ pain and underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. On the hospital ward postoperatively, the patient’s vital signs were T 41 C, HR 120 bpm, BP 130/70 mmHg, RR 30 bpm. Upon assessment, you noted diaphoresis, increased bowel sounds, and muscle rigidity in her lower extremities. What is the mechanism behind this condition?
questions.Summary: This is a case of serotonin syndrome due to the patient’s use of fluoxetine and recent surgery. It manifests as hyperthermia, increased bowel sounds, and  muscle rigidity acutely. The mechanism behind serotonin syndrome is an over activation of central and peripheral serotonin receptors.

choices.OptionStatement: Overactivation of central and peripheral serotonin receptors
choices.Reason: A is correct. This is the mechanism behind Serotonin syndrome.
B is incorrect. This is a mechanism of action of SSRIs and not the mechanism behind serotonin syndrome.
C is incorrect. This is a mechanism caused by amphetamines, cocaine, and mirtazipine that may cause serotonin syndrome but not the mechanism for the condition itself.

choices.OptionStatement: Increased serotonin release and activated serotonin receptors
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. These are mechanisms for associated drugs in serotonin syndrome, not the mechanism behind the condition.

questions.Keywords: Seizure, Postoperative delirium, Delayed emergence, Serotonin Syndrome, Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome, Malignant Hyperthermia
questions.References: Rosenberg H, Davis M, James D, Pollock N, Stowell K. Malignant hyperthermia. Orphanet J Rare Dis. 2007 Apr 24;2:21. doi: 10.1186/1750-1172-2-21. PMID: 17456235; PMCID: PMC1867813.
questions.Statement: You are called by your junior resident in the operating room to evaluate a patient shortly after induction of anesthesia. The patient appears to have developed a fever and the surgeon is complaining of the patient not being relaxed. You note a recent elevation in end-tidal CO2 and acidosis on blood gas analysis. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.Summary: This is a case of malignant hyperthermia which is associated with the combination of inhaled anesthetics and succinylcholine.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is a case of malignant hyperthermia that rarely occurs with intravenous anethestic use.

B is incorrect. Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic while midazolam is a sedative used in combination with an anesthetic for induction. This combination is not associated with a risk for malignant hyperthermia.
C is incorrect. Malignant hyperthermia is associated with the combination of an inhaled anesthetic and succinylcholine.
D is correct. Malignant hyperthermia is a common hyper metabolic response to the combination of an inhaled anesthetic and succinylcholine.

questions.Keywords: Central Nervous System, Cerebral Cortex, temporal lobe, parietal lobe, occipital lobe, frontal lobe
questions.References: K. H. Jawabri and S. Sharma, Physiology, Cerebral Cortex Functions. 2019.
questions.Statement: A 30 year old male was brought to the ER hours after a vehicular accident. The patient was noted to be extremely agitated and showed personality and behavioral changes. He had difficulty answering questions and was always roaming around. Which of the following bones has most likely been fractured?
questions.Summary: The frontal bone houses the frontal lobe and is most likely fractured in this case. The frontal lobe is responsible for speech and language, executive function, prospective memory, personality, reasoning, learning, creativity, and movement control.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The symptoms of this patient point to damage of the frontal lobe. The occipital bone could not have been fractured in this case.

B is correct. The frontal bone could have been fractured which led to symptoms of frontal lobe disruption. . Compromising two-thirds of the brain, the frontal lobe is responsible for speech and language, executive function, prospective memory, personality, reasoning, learning, creativity, and movement control.
C is incorrect. The parietal lobe is located posterior to the frontal lobe and damage to this would manifest as stereognosis, aphasia, and apraxia. This is a case of front lobe disruption.
D is incorrect. The temporal bone could not have been damaged as the symptoms point to a frontal lobe problem.

questions.Keywords: Central Nervous System, Cerebral Cortex, temporal lobe, parietal lobe, occipital lobe, frontal lobe
questions.References: Binder JR. The Wernicke area: Modern evidence and a reinterpretation. Neurology. 2015 Dec 15;85(24):2170-5. doi: 10.1212/WNL.0000000000002219. Epub 2015 Nov 13. PMID: 26567270; PMCID: PMC4691684.
questions.Statement: A 60 year old female diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and hypertension suddenly lost consciousness. En route to the emergency room, she regained consciousness. During examination, she had difficulty in answering questions and comprehending directions. Assuming her symptoms are due to an infarct, which area of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.Summary: This patient is suffering Wernicke’s aphasia which could be caused by an infarct in the Wernicke’s area located in the superior temporal gyrus.  Wernicke’s area has been historically associated with speech perception and comprehension but modern research has shown that Wernicke’s aphasia also includes a prominent speech production impairment.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The superior temporal gyrus houses Wernicke’s area, which is associated with speech perception and comprehension historically. With modern evidence, it has been found that Wernicke’s area actually have a larger role in speech production.

choices.OptionStatement: Medial surface of the temporal lobe
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. The medial surface of the temporal lobe is responsible for declarative memory.
C is incorrect. The superior parietal lobule is responsible for planned movements and attention.
D is incorrect. The inferior parietal lobule is involved in sensorimotor planning, learning, language, and spatial recognition.

questions.Keywords: Central Nervous System, Cerebral Cortex, temporal lobe, parietal lobe, occipital lobe, frontal lobe
questions.References: C. M. Klingner and O. W. Witte, “Somatosensory deficits,” in Handbook of Clinical Neurology, 2018.
questions.Statement:
A 12 year old patient was brought to the ER after falling off a tree. On examination, the patient had difficulty speaking and following commands. You also noted astereognosis (inability to recognize objects by touch) and loss of sensation in some regions.
Where is the lesion most likely located?
questions.Summary: The primary sensory cortex is housed in the anterior parietal lobe and this area is responsible for interpreting somatosensory signal it receives from the thalamus such as touch, pain, pressure, vibration, position, and temperature.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The temporal lobe is responsible for processing all sounds, speech perception and comprehension, and declarative memory. The patient demonstrated astereognosis which is not evident in temporal lobe lesions.
B is incorrect. The occipital lobe houses the visual cortex and is responsible for processing and interpreting visual stimulus.

C is incorrect. The frontal lobe is responsible for speech and language, executive function, prospective memory, personality, reasoning, learning, creativity, and movement control. This patient is less likely to have a lesion in the frontal lobe as there is no mention of behavioral or personality changes.

D is correct.  Lesions in the parietal lobe can lead to astereognosis (inability to identify objects by touch), aphasia (inability to form or understand speech), apraxia (inability to execute skilled movements), and sensory loss.

questions.Keywords: Basal Ganglia, Hippocampus, Internal Capsule, Cerebellum, Brain Stem, Reticular Activating System
questions.References: J. L. Lanciego, N. Luquin, and J. A. Obeso, “Functional neuroanatomy of the basal ganglia,” Cold Spring Harb. Perspect. Med., 2012, doi: 10.1101/cshperspect.a009621.
questions.Statement: A 16 year old male with a previous history of rheumatic fever, was brought in your clinic by his mother. The mother verbalized that the patient has recently been repeating phrases whenever spoken to. She also noted impulsive behavior and cuts on his wrist. Assuming these symptoms are due to a brain lesion, where is the most likely location?
questions.Summary: This is a case of Tourette’s syndrome commonly associated with streptococcal infections. A disruption of basal ganglia circuits is responsible for movement disorders and symptoms, such as Tourette’s syndrome and Parkinson’s disease. More recent research has shown that disruption of basal ganglia is associated with psychiatric disorders such as obsessive-compulsive disorder and alterations of moods.

choices.Reason: A is correct.  The basal ganglia is primarily responsible for motor learning, executive function and behavior, and emotions. Lesions in the basal ganglia have also been shown to be responsible for Tourette’s syndrome and obsessive-compulsive disorder which is the case in this question.
B is incorrect. The hippocampus functions primarily in learning and memory and makes up the posterior portion of the limbic system responsible for motivation, hunger, pain, pleasure, and libido.

C is incorrect. The cerebellum plays a role in cognition and motor control. Individuals with lesions in the cerebellum have difficulty with precision, experience erratic movements, and can lack coordination.
D is incorrect. The medulla contains the cardiac, respiratory, vomiting, and vasomotor control centers responsible for heart rate, respiratory rate, and blood pressure maintenance.

questions.Keywords: Basal Ganglia, Hippocampus, Internal Capsule, Cerebellum, Brain Stem, Reticular Activating System
questions.References: K. Anand and V. Dhikav, “Hippocampus in health and disease: An overview,” Annals of Indian Academy of Neurology. 2012, doi: 10.4103/0972-2327.104323.
questions.Statement: A 28 year old, female, postgraduate student with epilepsy, came in for memory problems. She complained she has difficulty retaining new information in her classes. She has been failing exams because she finds it hard to store new memory and asked for memory supplements. What structure is most likely affected?
questions.Summary: This is a case of anterograde amnesia associated with hippocampal sclerosis. Postmortem analyses have shown that 50-70% of patients with epilepsy have sclerosis of the hippocampus. The hippocampus is responsible for forming new episodic memories.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The basal ganglia  serve a crucial role in motor learning, executive function and behavior, and emotions, but not in forming new memory.
B is correct. The hippocampus functions primarily in learning and memory and makes up the posterior portion of the limbic system responsible for motivation, hunger, pain, pleasure, and libido.
C is incorrect. The cerebellum is primarily associated with motor control, precision, and coordination, but not forming new memories.
D is incorrect. The pons functions to carry information between the cerebrum, medulla, and cerebellum.

questions.Keywords: Basal Ganglia, Hippocampus, Internal Capsule, Cerebellum, Brain Stem, Reticular Activating System
questions.References:
M. C. Emos and S. Agarwal. Neuroanatomy, Internal Capsule. StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2022 Jan.
2022 Jun 13.
questions.Statement: A 60 year old hypertensive male collapsed at work. He presents to the ER awake and oriented, with face drooping and slurred speech. You wanted to localize the stroke lesion and ordered imaging studies. Which of the following is most likely affected?
questions.Summary: This patient presents with a lacunar stroke within the internal capsule. Occlusion or rupture of the corticobulbar fibers will present as face and tongue weakness and dysarthria.

choices.Reason: A is correct.  Infarct of the corticobulbar tract fibers presents as face and tongue weakness and dysarthria.

B is incorrect. This patient presents awake and oriented which will not manifest in infarcts of the frontopontine fibers. Lesions of the frontopontine fibers will present as confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.
C is incorrect. Lesions of the pyramidal and extrapyramidal tract will present as pure motor hemiparesis contralateral to the lesion location.
D is incorrect. Lesions of the posterior thalamic radiation fibers will present as contralateral hemisensory deficits.

questions.Keywords: Basal Ganglia, Hippocampus, Internal Capsule, Cerebellum, Brain Stem, Reticular Activating System
questions.References: M. Ngeles Fernández-Gil, R. Palacios-Bote, M. Leo-Barahona, and J. P. Mora-Encinas, “Anatomy of the brainstem: A gaze into the stem of life,” Semin. Ultrasound, CT MRI, 2010, doi: 10.1053/j.sult.2010.03.006.
questions.Statement: CSF flows between the third and fourth ventricles through this structure. Hence, narrowing of this structure leads to hydrocephalus.
questions.Summary: The cerebral aqueduct facilitates the passage of CSF between the third and fourth ventricles, and pathophysiology linked to cerebral aqueduct restriction can result in hydrocephalus that requires surgical treatment

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The cerebral peduncles connect the brainstem to the thalamus.
B is correct. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third and fourth ventricles and its narrowing can cause hydrocephalus.
C is incorrect. The superior colliculus is part of the midbrain that functions primarily in visual information processing.
D is incorrect. The red nucleus is located within the tegmentum and is associated with sensorimotor function.

questions.Keywords: Basal Ganglia, Hippocampus, Internal Capsule, Cerebellum, Brain Stem, Reticular Activating System
questions.References: Purves D, Augustine GJ, Fitzpatrick D, et al., editors. Neuroscience. 2nd edition. Sunderland (MA): Sinauer Associates; 2001. Consequences of Cerebellar Lesions. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK10942/
questions.Statement: A patient presented at the ER with gait instability. On neurologic examination, the patient failed the ‘finger-to-nose’ test. What zone of the cerebellum is affected?
questions.Summary: This patient presents with gait instability and failed the finger-to-nose test which are associated with lesions of the spinocerebellum.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. The main functions of this region include balance and eye movements. Lesions of this region impair a person’s ability to stand straight and keep looking in the same direction.

B is correct. The spinocerebellum's major function is to maintain muscular tone and coordinate motor activities. Lesions of this region lead to problems in controlling walking movements and intended actions such as the finger-to-nose test.
C is incorrect. When the cerebrocerebellum is damaged, learned actions that require high levels of expertise, like playing an instrument, are impaired.
D is incorrect. The flocculonodular lobe is another term for the vestibulocerebellum which is responsible for balance and eye movements.

questions.Keywords: Hypoxic-Ischemic Brain Injury, Global Ischemia, Cerebral Ischemia, Brain Ischemia, Anesthesia
questions.References: Busl KM, Greer DM. Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury: pathophysiology, neuropathology and mechanisms. NeuroRehabilitation. 2010;26(1):5-13. doi: 10.3233/NRE-2010-0531. PMID: 20130351.
questions.Statement: A 58 year old banker was found unconscious by his wife in his home office. He was rushed to the ER and ACLS was immediately started. After multiple rounds of CPR, the patient was eventually resuscitated. Which of the following is most true in this condition?
questions.Summary: Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is frequently associated with cardiac arrest due to the brain’s high metabolic demand. Hence, a lack of blood supply makes it very susceptible to damage.

choices.OptionStatement: Consciousness is lost within 10 seconds of cerebral blood flow loss. Within 3 minutes, the brain ceases to have spontaneous or evoked electrical activity.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Consciousness is lost within 10 seconds of cerebral blood flow loss. The human brain ceases to have spontaneous or evoked electrical activity within 20 seconds.

choices.OptionStatement: Accumulation of lactic acid leads to acidosis followed by depletion of the energy stores of tissue.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. The energy stores of tissue are the first to be depleted, followed by an accumulation of lactic acid causing acidosis, and finally, the blood brain barrier is altered and unable to maintain ion homeostasis

choices.OptionStatement: Within 10-12 minutes of ischemic onset, the brain is depleted of nearly all glucose, glycogen, adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and phosphocreatine
choices.Reason: C is correct. In animal studies, within 10-12 minutes of ischemic onset the brain is depleted of nearly all glucose, glycogen, adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and phosphocreatine.

choices.OptionStatement: The manifestation of major cell damage is dependent upon the type of injury
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. The manifestation of major cell damage is dependent upon the duration of injury and type of cells experiencing the ischemic insult

questions.Keywords: Hypoxic-Ischemic Brain Injury, Global Ischemia, Cerebral Ischemia, Brain Ischemia, Anesthesia
questions.References: I. Harukuni and A. Bhardwaj, “Mechanisms of brain injury after global cerebral ischemia,” Neurologic Clinics. 2006, doi: 10.1016/j.ncl.2005.10.004.
questions.Statement: A patient was brought into the ER, unconscious, with a stab wound at the left upper quadrant. The patient was severely hypotensive but was successfully resiscitated. What is the consequence of reperfusion to the brain?
questions.Summary: Reperfusion of the brain is needed to sustain life but also has its consequences. These include influx of neutrophils and reactive oxygen species, as well as cerebral edema and bleeding, which may result in secondary damage.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The maintenance of life requires the restoration of cerebral blood flow, but reperfusion also results in an influx of neutrophils and reactive oxygen species, as well as cerebral edema and bleeding, which may result in secondary damage.
B is incorrect. Reperfusion does not cause cellular necrosis. This is an effect of a lack of cerebral blood flow.
C is incorrect. Ventricular fibrillation is not caused by aggressive reperfusion but is a common etiology of global ischemia.
D is incorrect. Reperfusion does not cause embolism but an embolus may cause a focal ischemia.

questions.Keywords: Hypoxic-Ischemic Brain Injury, Global Ischemia, Cerebral Ischemia, Brain Ischemia, Anesthesia
questions.References: K. A. Hossmann, “The two pathophysiologies of focal brain ischemia: Implications for translational stroke research,” Journal of Cerebral Blood Flow and Metabolism. 2012, doi: 10.1038/jcbfm.2011.186.
questions.Statement: In focal ischemia, the infarct core refers to the:
questions.Summary: When a thromboembolic event occurs, the tissue immediately adjacent to the occluded vessel experiences the anoxia first and will, almost always, be the most severely affected region; this area is called the infarct core

choices.OptionStatement: The occluded vessel which experiences the anoxia first

choices.Reason: A is correct. This is a case of Treacher Collins syndrome which is caused by a mutation in the TCOF1 gene.

questions.Summary: The safest and most efficient procedure for general anesthesia is with the use of an intubating LMA for ventilation, followed by intubation with a cuffed tube over a flexible bronchoscope via the LMA.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The bleeding can likely be stopped by applying gentle pressure with a gloved finger with gauze.
B is incorrect. This is not indicated as this is just a consequence of dislodged blood clots which can be easily managed with gentle pressure.

choices.OptionStatement: Transferring the patient to the ICU
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. This is not warranted in this situation as this is just a consequence of dislodged blood clots which can be easily managed with gentle pressure.

choices.OptionStatement: Feeding the patient will stop the bleeding
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Keeping the patient on NPO is important in protecting the airway.

questions.Summary: It has been found that heart rate may increase with isoflurane, desflurane, and enflurane; halothane is more likely to case bradycardia. Halothane is no longer routinely used in the United States.

choices.Reason: C is incorrect. Halothane is not known to have cardioprotective effects.

questions.Summary: Sevoflurane is the best commonly available inhaled agent for asthmatic patients as it is odorless and causes the least degree of airway irritation. Other inhaled agents are more likely to cause airway irritation leading to laryngospasm.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Desflurane is not recommended in asthmatic patients since causes extensive airway irritation.

questions.Statement: A 10 year old boy is scheduled for an open appendectomy. He has been diagnosed with polycystic kidney disease for 1 year.  He is hemodynamically stable. The inhaled anesthetic of choice for this patient is:
questions.Summary: The metabolism of the halogenated agents produces fluoride which is believed to cause renal toxicity. The anesthetic of choice in this patient with renal disease should be the one which causes the least amount of fluoride production which is desflurane. In addition to polyuria and hypernatremia, fluoride toxicity increases serum osmolality.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Sevoflurane is metabolized the quickest and produces the highest levels of fluoride which is believed to cause renal toxicity, making this unsuitable for this patient.
B is incorrect. Isoflurane has been suggested to increase levels of fluoride, which is believed to cause renal toxicity, making this unsuitable for this patient.
C is incorrect. Halothane produces very little fluoride but is still not a suitable option for this patient as halothane has multiple adverse effects particularly in children.

questions.Statement: A 32 year old female diagnosed with fatty liver is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Vitals are stable and the patient is prepared for induction of inhaled anesthesia. Which of the following is most true about Halothane?
questions.Summary: All inhaled anesthetics have a moderate effect on hepatic blood flow. Halothane, on the other hand, has significant effects on the liver and should be avoided in patients with liver disease.

choices.OptionStatement: Halothane is metabolized 2-5% and mostly excreted
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Halothane is 25% metabolized by the hepatic CYP450 system.

choices.OptionStatement: Halothane’s chief breakdown product is acetic acid
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Halothane’s chief breakdown product is trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)

choices.OptionStatement: Halothane stimulates a T-cell mediated immune response
choices.Reason: C is correct. TFA is protein bound, and this complex has the capability to stimulate a T-cell mediated immune response resulting in fulminant hepatic failure.

choices.OptionStatement: Halothane has no effect on hepatic blood flow
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. All inhaled anesthetic agents tend to decrease hepatic blood flow.

questions.Statement: A 28 year old parturient asked for ‘laughing gas’ during delivery to relieve her pain. She returned to the clinic 3 weeks postpartum due to worsening hand numbness, laboratory results revealed megaloblastic anemia. What is the pathophysiology behind this condition?
questions.Summary: Nitrous oxide reduces the activity of methionine synthase, which is a crucial enzyme in the production of vitamin B12. B12 deficiency can lead to numerous problems including megaloblastic anemia and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. This condition may develop over the course of days.

choices.OptionStatement: Nitrous oxide decreases the activity of methionine synthase
choices.Reason: A is correct. Nitrous oxide reduces the activity of methionine synthase, which is a crucial enzyme in the production of vitamin B12.

choices.OptionStatement: Nitrous oxide increases the activity of methionine synthase
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Methionine synthase is an enzyme in the production of vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency would reveal decreased methionine enthuse activity.

choices.OptionStatement: A normal physiologic process of pregnancy
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. B12 deficiency is not common in uncomplicated pregnancies, but tends to occur with poor dietary intake.

choices.OptionStatement: Blood loss during delivery causes a decrease in vitamin B12
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Blood loss is associated with iron deficiency anemia or hemolytic anemias, not megaloblastic anemia.

questions.Statement: A 34 year old obese, non-smoker is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He is hemodynamically stable and has been on NPO for 8 hours. Which inhaled anesthetic agent has the properties of rapid recovery and low oil/gas partition coefficient?
questions.Summary: Desflurane is the anesthetic of choice in this patient due to its low oil/gas partition coefficient and quick onset and offset of action suitable for short procedures.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Sevoflurane is the most commonly used inhalation induction agent but does not have a quick offset of action.

C is incorrect. Isoflurane has a high blood:gas solubility therefore it has a very slow onset and offset of action. It also has high fat solubility making it unsuitable for this patient.
D is incorrect. Halothane is no longer used in the United States due to its multiple adverse effects and high incidence of ventricular arrhythmias and significant hepatotoxicity.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old patient underwent adenoidectomy under general anesthesia and neuromuscular blockade. After the procedure, the patient was able to open his eyelids. At the PACU, the nurse noted laryngospasm characterized by stridor. What is the best course of action?
questions.Summary: Laryngospasm is a common occurrence after extubation in patients emerging from general anesthesia.  Jaw thrust maneuver and CPAP of up to 40 cmH2O usually breaks the laryngospasm.

choices.OptionStatement: Check for 5 second sustained head lift

choices.Reason: B is incorrect. A tracheal tube should not be forced through a closed glottis during laryngospasm

questions.Statement: A 52 year old obese male with obstructive sleep apnea underwent external fixation of his femur. He is hemodynamically stable. When will you extubate this patient?

choices.Reason: C is correct. Patients with obstructive sleep apnea should be extubated while fully awake and following commands.

questions.Statement: A 40 year old obese patient was recently transferred to the PACU after modified radical mastectomy. When the patient was awake, she suddenly became dyspneic and O2 saturation dropped to 82%. On auscultation, fine crackles were noted.What is your immediate management?
questions.Summary: Pulmonary atelectasis is a common complication of general anesthesia.  Transitioning the patient to a sitting position, utilizing incentive spirometry, and positive airway pressure with facemask can treat atelectasis.

choices.OptionStatement: Reintubate the patient and initiate mechanical ventilation
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Reintubation should be avoided as much as possible as mortality rate is is significantly increased in reintubated patients.

questions.Statement: A 52 year old female patient is scheduled for modified radical mastectomy.  Her medical history includes diabetes and hypertension that are both well-controlled. What is your anesthetic of choice?
questions.Summary: Propofol is the most common intravenous anesthetic and evidence suggests that it has a moderate effect on reducing contractility of the heart and decreasing systemic vascular resistance.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Thiopental is not suitable for this patient since she is hypertensive. Thiopental leads to a direct negative inotropic action and increased capacitance of the venous system which results in a decrease in filling of the ventricles. This manisfests as relative or frank hypotension which poses the risk of ischemia.
B is correct. Propofol is the agent of choice as it has a moderate effect on reducing contractility of the heart and decreasing systemic vascular resistance.
C is incorrect. Desflurane leads to a dose-dependent decrease in blood pressure due to decreases in systemic vascular resistance which may lead to hypotension.
D is incorrect. Halothane causes attenuation of cardiac contractile function which may lead to hypotension.  It is no longer available in the United States due to multiple adverse effects.

questions.Summary: Perioperative myocardial infarction is a frequent complication in patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing surgical procedures. Management will depend on the symptoms, hemodynamic stability, and ECG evidence of ischemia. This patient has a history of cardiovascular disease and revealed NSTEMI. Betablockers are the best initial agents out of the supplied options.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Cardioversion is not indicated in patients without arrhythmia.
B is correct. Control of heart rate and blood pressure with beta-blockers is enough to decrease myocardial oxygen demand and has been shown to decrease mortality rates.
C is incorrect. This is not recommended early in the postoperative course due to the increased risk of bleeding.
D is incorrect. Cardiology consults are only indicated in ST-elevation and elevated troponin levels.

questions.Statement: A 36 year old diabetic female, non-smoker,  with a history of motion sickness will undergo bilateral oophorectomy. In order to prevent post-operative nausea and vomiting, what is your management?
questions.Summary: Non-smoking female patients with a history of motion sickness are at an increased risk of PONV and are managed preoperatively to prevent its occurrence and increase patient satisfaction. This risk increases with the planned administration of opioid analgesics.

choices.OptionStatement: Place a scopolamine patch in high-risk patients
choices.Reason: A is correct. The patient in this case is considered high-risk (female, non-smoking, history of motion sickness) hence a scopolamine patch is indicated.

choices.OptionStatement: Give 2 doses of Pregabalin 12 hours apart pre-operatively

questions.Statement: A 42 year old female patient with Parkinson's disease is scheduled for a modified radical mastectomy. She has been taking Levodopa/Carbidopa for 2 years and has had no problems. She is hemodynamically stable. What is your anesthetic of choice?
questions.Summary: Propofol is still the agent of choice in patients with Parkinson’s disease as it has anti-parkinsonian effects and has a favorable anesthetic profile.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The anesthetic of choice is propofol. Despite its increased risk for dyskinesia, propofol is the agent of choice due to its favorable anesthetic effects and some anti-parkinsonian effects.
B is incorrect. Although the effects of this are still unclear, thiopental inhibits dopamine release at the striatal level which may exacerbate symptoms.
C is incorrect. Ketamine may cause an exaggerated sympathetic response when used with levodopa, so it should be used with caution.

D is incorrect. Volatile anesthetics are better avoided in Parkinson’s disease as they have been suggested to stimulate dopamine release and inhibit uptake in rat models. Sevoflurane may also cause hypotension which may be exaggerated in Parkinson’s disease.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old patient, with Parkinson’s disease, recently underwent tonsillectomy.  5 hours post-op, she complained of pain and nausea and asked for a medication. Which of the following will you avoid in this patient?
questions.Summary: Metoclopramide is contraindicated in post-operative patients with Parkinson’s disease due to its dopamine antagonistic actions which may worsen symptoms.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Acetaminophen is safe to use in patients with Parkinson’s disease.
B is correct. Metoclopramide is avoided in this patient as it may worsen symptoms due to its dopamine antagonistic actions.
C is incorrect. Ibuprofen is safe to use in patients with Parkinson’s disease.
D is incorrect. Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 antagonist and is safe to use in Parkinson’s disease. It has not been shown to worsen PD symptoms.

questions.Statement: A 27 year old engineer accidentally struck his hand with a hammer and acquired a laceration that needed to be sutured to stop the bleeding. An alkalinized solution of mepivacaine was utilized to anesthetize the site. What is the explanation behind the pain reduction of the injection with the alkalinisation of local anesthetics?
questions.Summary: Evidence supports a reduction on pain on injection when sodium bicarbonate used to alkalinize local anesthetics.  This is due to the more rapid onset of action rather than the increase in pH.

choices.OptionStatement: The more rapid onset offers a faster reduction of pain
choices.Reason: A is correct. Evidence supports that the more rapid onset is the reason behind the pain reduction and not the increased pH.

choices.OptionStatement: The increase in pH leads to increased lipid solubility
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Although this statement is true, the increase in pH is not the immediate cause of the pain reduction.

choices.OptionStatement: The increase in the amount of non-ionized drug
choices.Reason: C is incorrect.  Alkalinisation leads to an increase in non-ionized drug which leads to increased lipid solubility but this is not the immediate cause of the pain reduction.

choices.OptionStatement: It increases shelf life and stability leading to a more enhanced effect
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. This does not explain the reason behind pain reduction.

questions.Statement: A 25 year old parturient is in the second stage of labor and is requesting pain relief. Her vitals are stable and she reports no allergies. What is your analgesic approach of choice?

choices.OptionStatement: Epirual injetion of an alkalinized local anesthtetic
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Adding sodium bicarbonate to epidural anesthetics speeds up the onse of action, but only by a few minutes. choices.OptionStatement: Intrathecal injetion of an alkalinized local anesthtetic
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Alkalinization of an intrathecal anesthetic is not typically needed as this route already provides rapid onset.

choices.OptionStatement: Epidural catheter with a diluted local anesthetic solution
choices.Reason: D is correct. Administering an epidural without alkalinization remains the best option in non-urgent vaginal deliveries.

questions.Statement: A 35 year old author consulted your clinic for neck pain and frequent headaches. She takes no antihypertensive medications but takes phenelzine for her depressive disorder. She frequently pairs wine with cheese whenever she’s writing. On physical examination, her vitals were T-37.5 C, HR- 110 bpm, BP- 160/80 mmHg, and RR- 20 bpm. What is your recommendation?
questions.Summary: This patient is experiencing MAOI toxicity due to drug interaction with tyramine. Management of MAOI toxicity would depend on the case but after ensuring a patent airway, treatment is largely symptomatic.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Anti-hypertensive medications are not warranted in MAOI induced hypertension, but lowering blood pressure with nitroprusside is commonly done as it is short-acting.
B is incorrect. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in MAOI toxicity as this may result in potentiation of alpha stimulation.

choices.OptionStatement: Rapid infusion of cold crystalloid intravenous fluid
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. This will not manage the patient’s elevated blood pressure and is only reserved for patients who are febrile.
D is incorrect. Cyproheptadine is sometimes suggested due to its anticholinergic and antiserotonergic effects. There is currently not enough evidence to prove its efficacy.

choices.OptionStatement: Tapered decrease over 2-3 weeks before discontinuation

questions.Statement: A 30 year old asthmatic patient, taking Omeprazole and Montelukast, underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. After the procedure, the patient complained of moderate pain at the surgical site. What is your analgesic of choice?
questions.Summary: NSAIDs are commonly used in the treatment of mild to moderate postoperative pain. NSAIDs have different COX inhibition specificity and vary in both the analgesic and side effect profile of each medication.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Since the patient is taking Omeprazole, she is likely diagnosed with gastrointestinal reflux, and a COX-2 inhibitor would be most ideal as it has lesser gastrointestinal side effects.
B is incorrect. Ibuprofen is a nonselective NSAID and would not be suitable for this patient with gastrointestinal problems.
C is incorrect. Naproxen is a COX-1 inhibitor and has greater gastrointestinal adverse effects.
D is incorrect. Tylenol’s COX inhibition is yet to be fully determined and wouldn’t be the best option for this patient.

questions.Statement: A 58 year old patient consulted your clinic for right frozen shoulder persisting for 5 months that has been severely affecting his daily activities. Upon assessment, he had difficulty touching his scapula and cannot raise his arm due to the pain. What is your management?
questions.Summary: An interscalene block is used in upper arm procedures proximal to the elbow. This is a case of a frozen shoulder and would most benefit from an interscalene block.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. NSAIDs may be useful in early frozen shoulder but will not be of significant use in the case.

questions.Statement: A 30 year old veterinarian was attacked by a rabid dog. This led to avulsion of the 2nd and 3rd digits which needed immediate repair. In preparation for hand surgery, the anesthesiologist administered a peripheral nerve block. What was most likely given?
questions.Summary: The axillary block is the most common block for surgeries involving the hand since it has lesser complications.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Cervical plexus block covers branches C2- C4 and superior shoulder procedures. The hand would be very distant from the site of injection.
B is incorrect. Interscalene block is indicated in upper arm procedures proximal to the elbow making it unsuitable for hand procedures.
C is incorrect. The supraclavicular block may be suitable for this patient as it provides better tourniquet tolerance but has an increased risk of pneumothorax and phrenic nerve paralysis.

D is correct. This is the most suitable block as it is good for surgery distal to the elbow specially the forearm and the hand. It is also a better option over the supraclavicular block since it avoids the risk of pneumothorax and phrenic nerve paralysis.

questions.Statement: A 64 year old male was scheduled for hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis. He has been suffering from chronic pain for years and finally decided to get the surgery. What is your plan for postoperative management of pain?
questions.Summary: Following hip or thigh surgeries as well as for persistent pain issues, lumbar plexus blocks are utilized to anesthetize the lower extremity.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. While a spinal anesthetic may be appropriate for surgical analgesia, it is relatively short-lived and not suitable for postoperative pain control.

B is correct. Lumbar plexus blocks are indicated for surgeries of the hip, anterior thigh, or knee and can even provide anesthesia to the entire lower extremity when combined with sciatic nerve block. Care must be taken due to the proximity to vascular structures.
C is incorrect. A femoral block can be considered a good alternative but has a risk factor for falls (due to a quadriceps motor block) and is reserved for analgesia of mid shaft femoral fractures.
D is incorrect. A saphenous nerve block is commonly used as a supplement to sciatic nerve block for lower extremity surgery of the medial portion of the foot or leg.

questions.Statement: A 12 year old boy had a bicycle accident near his home. He severed two of his toes as they got caught in the spokes of the wheel. The patient was brought to the ER and immediately scheduled for foot surgery.  Which peripheral nerve block would be most applicable in this case?
questions.Summary: Surgeries of the foot would benefit from a sciatic nerve block as it offers complete anesthetia of the foot.

questions.Statement: A 70 year old patient is admitted in the ICU due to ARDS. An indwelling arterial catheter has been in place for 2 days when an absent pulse, mottled skin, and delayed capillary refill was noted by the nurse. What is your initial management?
questions.Summary: Arterial catheterization is associated with distal ischemia due to thrombotic occlusion. Management depends on the underlying cause of the ischemia.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. If intra-arterial drug delivery or arteriography are not being considered, the catheter should be taken out to ensure it is not obstructing the flow. Although a good option, removal of a catheter without being sure of the cause might be counterproductive.

D is incorrect. Hot compresses may relieve vasospasm but this case is more likely due to a thrombus.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. This is reserved for large-bore needle punctures.

choices.OptionStatement: Keep the needle in place to prevent hemothorax
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. This case involved a small gauge needle puncture and would not typically cause a hemothorax.

choices.OptionStatement: Remove the needle and apply external pressure
choices.Reason: C is correct. This is the best answer as a small gauge needle would unlikely cause a hemothorax. Applying external pressure for a few minutes will likely prevent hematoma formation.

choices.OptionStatement: Suture the puncture site to prevent hemothorax
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. There will most likely be nothing to suture in small needle punctures; in large bore needle punctures suturing the site would also be futile as surgical exploration would most likely be initiated.

questions.Statement: A medical intern is inserting a pulmonary artery catheter in a patient admitted in the ICU who underwent recent coronary bypass grafting. The patient is mechanically ventilated via SIMV mode and is hemodynamically stable. After the insertion, the patient suddenly vomited blood. What is the immediate management?
questions.Summary: Pulmonary artery rupture is a rare complication of pulmonary artery cathetertization and requires immediate control of hemorrhage. The first priority is ensuring adequate oxygenation which may require endobronchial intubation.

choices.OptionStatement: Ensure adequate oxygenation with endobronchial intubation
choices.Reason: A is correct. The first priority in pulmonary artery rupture is ensuring adequate oxygenation and may require endobronchial intubation with a single- or double-lumen endotracheal tube to selectively ventilate and protect the unaffected lung.

choices.OptionStatement: Ensure adequate oxygenation with positive end-expiratory pressure
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. This may help control hemorrhage but would not be the priority in this patient.
C is incorrect. Bronchoscopy would localize and control the site of bleeding but is not a priority in this situation

questions.Summary: The best approach for visualizing major cardiac structures is through transesophageal echocardiography. It is also utilized in patients who cannot tolerate position changes.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. A transesophageal echocardiography is utilized when a patient is unable to move into a left lateral decubitus position.
B is incorrect. This is not recommended for critically ill patients.
C is correct. Transesophageal echocardiography provides better visualization of most heart structures and vessels and is indicated in patients who cannot move into a lateral decubitus position.

questions.Summary: The only widely accepted absolute contraindications to TEE are esophageal stricture, fistula, trauma or prior esophageal surgery.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Coagulopathy is only a relative contraindication to TEE.
B is incorrect. Hiatal hernia is only a relative contraindication to TEE.
C is incorrect. Facial trauma is only a relative contraindication to TEE.
D is correct. Prior esophageal surgery is an absolute contraindication to TEE.

questions.Statement: In standard transesophageal echocardiography examination, withdrawing means:
questions.Summary: Pushing the probe distally, towards the stomach, is called advancing the transducer while pulling the tip more proximally is called withdrawing.

choices.OptionStatement: Pushing the probe towards the stomach
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Pushing the probe towards the stomach is called advancing the transducer.

choices.OptionStatement: Pushing the probe towards the spine

choices.OptionStatement: Pulling the probe towards the sternum

questions.Summary: Preoperative TTE has been shown to influence anesthetic management with respect to delaying/canceling non-essential surgery, escalation/de-escalation of management, guide the choice of vasopressors intraoperatively, and help with the decision to use or forgo invasive hemodynamic monitoring

questions.Statement: Which of the following is true regarding intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography?
questions.Summary: IOTEE should be used in all open heart procedures, septal defect closure, atrial appendage obliteration, and CABG. It is also recommended in some non-cardiac procedures.

choices.OptionStatement: It provides a timely assessment of the duration of the surgical procedure.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. IOTEE provides a timely assessment of the surgical result not the duration.

choices.OptionStatement: It should be used in all septal defect closure procedures.
choices.Reason: B is correct. IOTEE should be used in all open heart, transcatheter intracardiac procedures under general anesthesia without intracardiac ultrasound, septal defect closure, atrial appendage obliteration, catheter-based valve replacement/repair, and thoracic aortic procedures and is utilized in coronary artery bypass graft surgeries.

choices.OptionStatement: It is recommended in certain non-cardiac surgeries such as in emergency appendectomy.
choices.Reason: C is incorrect.  IOTEE is also recommended in certain non-cardiac surgeries; such as: lung transplantation or major thoracoabdominal trauma.
D is incorrect. It identifies surgical complications.

questions.Statement: At a specific lung volume and without any active air movement, static pressure is measured at the mouth. What is this representative of?
questions.Summary: Alveolar pressure is a component of total lung static pressure which is measured at the mouth with no air movement.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  Compliance is the amount of volume change with a given pressure.
B is incorrect. Plateau pressure is representative of lung compliance.
C is incorrect. This is representative of potential stress on the lung parenchyma
D is correct. Alveolar pressure is representative of static pressure measures at the mouth with no air movement at a certain volume.

questions.Statement: In setting up mechanical ventilation, there are variables to consider that affect that delivery of a breath. A trigger is the parameter that tells the ventilator to deliver that breath. Which of the following does not control the trigger?
questions.Summary: A trigger may be ventilator-driven, time-driven (e.g., every 10 seconds to provide 6 breaths per minute), or patient-driven in response to the patient's effort as evidenced by the negative pressure or flow that is produced by the patient.

choices.Reason: A is not the exemption. A trigger can be ventilator driven.
B is not the exemption. A trigger can also be time driven.
C is not the exemption. A patient driven trigger is based on patient effort from negative pressure or flow generated by the patient.
D is the exemption. Pressure does not affect the trigger.

questions.Statement: What is the independent variable that determines the mode of ventilation?
questions.Summary: Flow, volume, or pressure are the three main variables to aim for. The target variable is “dialed” into the ventilator when initiating mechanical ventilation. The mode of ventilation—pressure controlled, pressure support, or volume controlled—is determined by this independent variable.

choices.Reason: A is correct. The target variable is set onto the ventilator at the initiation of mechanical ventilation. This is the independent variable and determines the mode of ventilation.
B is incorrect. The trigger tells the ventilator to deliver a breath.
C is incorrect. Breath termination is determined by inspiratory time, volume, or flow and does not determine the mode of ventilation.
D is incorrect. The flow-time scalar provides information about the inspiratory and expiratory cycle.

questions.Statement: It is important to have a deep understanding of the different ventilator scalars. What does a flow-time loop that plateaus without reaching zero indicate?
questions.Summary: Expiratory volume tracing that declines, plateaus, but doesn't reach zero is a sign that there's a leak.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. A decreased peak expiratory flow indicates bronchospasm or accumulation of secretions.
B is incorrect. A prolonged expiratory time is equivalent to a decreased peak expiratory flow, indicating bronchospasm.
C is incorrect. An expiratory flow curve that does not reach zero and the subsequent breath starting below baseline are signs of air trapping.
D is correct. A graph that plateaus but does not return to zero is indicative of an air leak around the endotracheal tube or from the circuit.

questions.Statement: This mode of mechanical ventilation depends on the patient to initiate a breath in order to deliver a pressure flow based on their inspiratory effort.
questions.Summary: Presssure-support ventilation is a mode of ventilation that delivers a programmed pressure initiated by the patient’s breath.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Variable tidal volume results from the ventilator being set to a driving pressure that is then provided to the patient. The respiratory system's compliance and resistance will affect the resulting tidal volume.

B is correct. In pressure-support ventilation (PSV), all breaths are initiated by the patient. Once activated, the ventilator produces a predetermined pressure, and the patient receives the pressure flow dependent on their effort to inhale.
C is incorrect. This ventilation method can be either volume- or pressure-controlled. The patient receives a rate-based ventilator breath after dialing in a predetermined rate, pressure, or volume.

D is incorrect. A predetermined number of required ventilator breaths, which may be volume- or pressure-based breaths, are administered to the patient. The ventilator tries to synchronize a spontaneous respiratory effort to a mandatory breath based on the patient starting a breath during a timed window. Spontaneous respiratory efforts are allowed in between the mandatory breaths.

questions.Statement: This mode of mechanical ventilation promotes lung recruitment by allowing prolonged inspiratory times and continuous positive airway pressure with release times. Which of the following statements is true about this mode of ventilation?
questions.Summary: The inverse ratio ventilation mode permits extended inspiratory durations and sustained positive airway pressure with release times. It also promotes lung recruitment.

choices.OptionStatement: The “pressure high” is typically the same airway plateau pressure measured during conventional ventilation
choices.Reason: A is correct.  This mode of ventilation is known as the inverse ratio ventilation. It promotes lung recruitment by allowing prolonged inspiratory times and continuous positive airway pressure with release times.

choices.OptionStatement: The “pressure low” is a much shorter time, typically between 1 and 2 seconds
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. The “pressure low” typically ranges between 0.6 and 0.7 seconds.

choices.OptionStatement: The pressure high is dependent on the patient’s lung physiology and disease state
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. The pressure low is dependent on the patient’s lung physiology and disease state.

choices.OptionStatement: Hypocarbia easily occurs in this mode
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Hypercarbia is likely to occur in this mode.

questions.Keywords: agonist, antagonist, affinity, potency, dose-response, synergy
questions.References: Katzung & Trevor Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, 2017; Chapter 2: Drug Receptors & Pharmacodynamics
questions.Statement: These medications work by preventing the agonist molecule from attaching to the receptor but do not cause the signal to be produced:
questions.Summary: The biological effects of the agonist are inhibited when a competitive antagonist attaches to the receptor and prevents the agonist from binding.

choices.Reason: A is correct. A competitive antagonist binds to the receptor and prevents the agonist from binding, blocking the agonist's biologic actions.
B is incorrect. A partial agonist binds to one of the receptor’s secondary sites leading to the same effect as the main drug but with a lower intensity.
C is incorrect. An inverse agonist produces effects opposite to the agonist but binds to the same receptor site as the agonist.
D is incorrect. An agonist mimics the action of the signal ligand by binding to and activating a receptor.

questions.Keywords: agonist, antagonist, affinity, potency, dose-response, synergy
questions.References: Katzung & Trevor Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, 2017; Chapter 2: Drug Receptors & Pharmacodynamics
questions.Statement: This medication prevents the physiologic effect of the agonist from occurring despite binding on a secondary site.
questions.Summary: A non-competitive antagonist prevents activation of the receptor by attaching to an allosteric (non-agonist) secondary site on the receptor. An agonist binding to the receptor primary site will no longer elicit a response, and raising the agonist concentration will not have any physiological effects.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. A reversible antagonist binds non-covalently to the receptor and therefore can have its effect diminished by increasing the concentration of the agonist.
B is incorrect. An irreversible antagonist binds covalently to the receptor and cannot be displaced by increasing the concentration of the agonist.
C is correct. A non-competitive antagonist binds to an allosteric secondary site on the receptor to prevent activation of the receptor.
D is incorrect. An allosteric modulator binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site which induces conformational changes in the receptor.

questions.Keywords: agonist, antagonist, affinity, potency, dose-response, synergy
questions.References: Katzung & Trevor Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, 2017; Chapter 2: Drug Receptors & Pharmacodynamics
questions.Statement: Which of the following drugs directly binds to the opioid receptors but does not cause a physiologic response?
questions.Summary: The question describes a competitive antagonist which is represented by naloxone. It is an opioid receptor competitive antagonist which directly binds to the opioid receptors but does not cause a physiologic response.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Fentanyl is a direct opioid receptor agonist.
B is correct. Naloxone is an opioid receptor competitive antagonist which directly binds to the opioid receptors but does not cause a physiologic response.
C is incorrect. Ketamine is a noncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist that binds in an allosteric secondary site on the receptor to prevent activation of the receptor.
D is incorrect. Methadone is a full agonist that mimics the action of the signal ligand by activating a receptor.

questions.Statement: A 5 year old girl is scheduled for tonsillectomy due to frequent acute tonsillopharyngitis. She is hemodynamically stable. She is asthmatic but is well-controlled. Which of the following anesthetics would you use as an induction agent in this patient?
questions.Summary: Sevoflurane is the preferred induction agent in the pediatric population due to its rapid onset and offset and has very minimal odor, decreasing airway complications.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Sevoflurane is the agent of choice in the pediatric population as it has a rapid onset and rapid recovery and has minimal odor.
B is incorrect. Desflurane is avoided for induction due to its pungent odor which increases the risk for laryngospasm due to airway irritation.
C is incorrect. Isoflurane is avoided in induction as it also has a pungent odor and has a slower onset and offset.
D is incorrect. Halothane has a very high risk of triggering airway reflexes and greater incidence of adverse events.

questions.Statement: A 12 year old girl with DM type 1 is scheduled for an appendectomy.  Her vital signs are within normal range. Her mother tells you that she is typically irritable and would likely not tolerate the OR environment. What is your intravenous induction agent of choice?
questions.Summary: Propofol is the intravenous drug of choice for induction in hemodynamically stable adult and perdiatric patients as it is associated with a smooth recovery and has a rapid onset and offset.

choices.Reason: A is correct. Propofol is the agent of choice as it is short acting. It is also associated with a smooth recovery because it protects from and treats emergence agitation.
B is incorrect. Etomidate is more commonly used in hypovolemia and cardiovascular disease. It is not suitable for this patient since it adds the risk of adrenal suppression.
C is incorrect. Thiopental is rarely used in the pediatric population as it causes excessively prolonged effects due to increased beta-elimination.
D is incorrect. Ketamine is commonly used in hemodynamic instability because it causes catecholamine release. It may also be linked to an increased incidence of emergence agitation.

questions.Statement: A 6 year old boy recently underwent kidney transplant. His vitals at bedside were within the normal range. He is complaining of severe pain and his mother requested for something to alleviate it. What is your medication of choice?
questions.Summary: Remifentanil is an ultra short-acting opioid which is not affected by hepatic or renal function.

choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Meperidine is not recommended in the pediatric population due to its risk of causing seizures, especially in patients with renal dysfunction.
B is incorrect. Codeine is unsuitable for children below 12 years of age due to its risk of respiratory complications.
C is incorrect. Oxymorphone is not routinely given in the pediatric population due to its high risk of addiction and abuse. It also has an increased risk of respiratory depression.
D is correct. Remifentanil is the preferred option for this patient as it has a short half life and is not affected by hepatic or renal function.

questions.Statement: A 12 year old patient with Becker’s muscular dystrophy is induced for spinal fusion surgery. In PACU, the patient complained of severe leg pain and bloodwork revealed a serum CK-MM of 300 U/L. What was most likely given to this patient?
questions.Summary: Succinylcholine is avoided in patients with muscular dystrophy as it is known to cause hyperkalemia and rhabdomyolysis.

choices.Reason: A is correct. This is a case of acute rhabdomyolysis. Succinylcholine is contraindicated in patients with muscular dystrophy due to its risk of hyperkalemia and fatal rhabdomyolysis.
B is incorrect. Halothane is associated with cardiovascular and respiratory instability. It is also associated with liver toxicity.
C is incorrect. Methohexital is associated with muscular hyperactivity, hiccups, and myoclonus. It is also out of routine clinical practice.
D is incorrect. Etomidate is frequently associated with pain, myoclonus, and laryngospasm but not rhabdomyolysis.

questions.Statement: Local anesthetics have different effects in children and adults. Which of the following is true?
questions.Summary: Children absorb local anesthetics more quickly than adults do, have higher cardiac output and regional tissue blood flows, and have less adipose tissue in some anatomical areas. These factors affect the pharmacokinetics of local anesthetics in children.

choices.OptionStatement: Half-life is shortened in neonates due to greater volumes of distribution.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  With greater volumes of distribution in neonates, half-life is prolonged compared to adults.

choices.OptionStatement: Protein binding is increased in neonates leading to greater risk of CNS toxicity.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Protein binding is decreased in neonates, reducing drug metabolism and leading to a greater risk of CNS toxicity since a greater proportion of the drug is unbound

choices.OptionStatement: Reduced plasma cholinesterase activity in neonates and infants
choices.Reason: C is correct. Neonates and infants have reduced plasma cholinesterase activity, which results in slower metabolism of ester anesthetics.

choices.OptionStatement: Hepatic blood flood is increased in neonates due to less body surface area.
choices.Reason: D is incorrect. Hepatic enzymes are immature in neonates and hepatic blood flow is decreased.

questions.Statement: According to the ACC/AHA preoperative guidelines, which of the following is true?
questions.Summary: The ACC/AHA has provided guidelines on preoperative cardiovascular evaluation and management of patients undergoing non cardiac surgery.

choices.OptionStatement: A healthy patient undergoing a low risk procedure requires no laboratory testing.
choices.Reason: A is correct. No laboratory testing and no electrocardiogram (ECG) are required for a healthy patient having a low risk surgery.

choices.OptionStatement: Patients who can perform greater than or equal to 3 metabolic equivalents (METs) require no further testing.
choices.Reason: B is incorrect. Patients who can perform greater than or equal to 4 metabolic equivalents (METs) require no further testing.

choices.OptionStatement: Preoperative tests should be ordered routinely
choices.Reason: C is incorrect. The ASA published a Practice Advisory for Pre-anesthesia Evaluation in 2012 that offered recommendations on particular laboratory tests and the supporting data. According to their findings, preoperative tests should not be routinely ordered and there is insufficient data to support particular testing decision-making guidelines.

choices.OptionStatement: Urgent surgery is defined as life, limb, or organ is threat if surgical intervention does not occur within 1 to 6 hours.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect. Urgent surgery is defined by life, limb, or organ threat if surgical intervention does not occur within 6 to 24 hours.

questions.References: Szocik J, Barker SJ, Tremper KK. Chapter 44 - Fundamental Principles of Monitoring Instrumentation.  From: Miller’s Anesthesia, 8th ed. R.D. Miller, NH Cohen, L.I. Erikkson, et al. ed. Philadelphia, PA, Elsevier Saunders, 2015
questions.Statement: Understanding and managing the operation of volatile anesthetics requires an understanding of partial pressures. Which of the following is true about partial pressures?
questions.Summary: The quantity of anesthetic gas being given through a vaporizer and into the anesthesia circuit is, instead of being expressed as partial pressures, expressed as a percentage of the mix of gases.

choices.OptionStatement: The quantity of anesthetic gas exiting a vaporizer into the anesthesia circuit is expressed as partial pressures.
choices.Reason: A is incorrect.  The quantity of anesthetic gas being given through a vaporizer and into the anesthesia circuit is, instead of being expressed as partial pressures, expressed as a percentage of the mix of gases.

choices.OptionStatement: The partial pressure of a volatile anesthetic can be calculated
choices.Reason: B is correct.  The partial pressure of a volatile anesthetic in a carrier gas mixture can be calculated.

choices.OptionStatement: Boyles's law states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each of the constituent gases.
choices.Reason: C is incorrect.  Dalton's law states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each of the constituent gases. Boyle's law states that at constant temperature the volume of a given mass of a dry gas is inversely proportional to its pressure.

choices.OptionStatement: Variable bypass vaporizers calibrated for a given agent at a baseline assumed atmospheric pressure will release anesthetic vapor under a specific concentration.
choices.Reason: D is incorrect.  Variable bypass vaporizers calibrated for a given agent at a baseline pressure (assumed atmospheric pressure) will release anesthetic vapor under a given partial pressure, and not a specific concentration.

questions.Statement: The undesirable effect of resonance within a pressure sensing system (such as the arterial line sensor) is offset by:
questions.Summary: The undesirable effect of resonance within the system is offset by making the natural frequency of the measuring system as high as possible  and by damping, which lowers the natural frequency of the system and keeping it from approaching its natural frequency.

choices.OptionStatement: Making the natural frequency of the measuring system as low as possible
choices.Reason: A incorrect. It is by making the natural frequency of the measuring system as high as possible that offsets the undesirable effect of resonance.
B is correct. Damping offsets the undesirable effect of resonance. It is a way of lowering the natural frequency of the system and keeping it from approaching its natural frequency.
C is incorrect. Making sure that the transducer is zeroed will not offset the undesirable effect of resonance.
D is incorrect. Narrow tubing will increase damping but won’t offset the undesirable effect of resonance.
